original_comment: Correct! By developing the knight to c3 we gain some control over central e4/d5 squares, as well as we win an important tempo since black queen is attacked. Then, it will be possible to develop another piece, Nf3 or Bc4.Following opening principles:- DEVELOPMENT - the knight is actually developed from its starting point,- CENTER- the knight takes some control over central e4/d5 squares,- CASTLE- maybe here it is not directly the case, but we are one step closer to castle long, and also by winning time on the black queen, we will be able develop one of the kingside minor pieces, which obviously helps preparing short castling.But what is wrong with black setup?RULE OF THUMB:Do not bring your queen to the game too early! First of all, it may become a target for the enemy pieces, moreover it sometimes block the way to develop minor pieces and it's not associated with their development etc.
Correct! Attacked knight turns back to the safe square with tempo (attaking black's bishop), and then white is ready to play d2-d4 (center) and develop like Nf3, Bc4 and 0-0.

Correct! Do you remember we highlight after f2-f3 at the very early stage the king is less safe? Due to open e1-h4 diagonal, there is a double attack on e1 and e4. After Ke2 black just takes on e4 with check, but after g2-g3...
... there is one more double attack and black wins the whole rock.
And this one works again.
Follow with the most popular 2.Nf3

Here you go again on your own :)Actually, it is better not to accept the knight sacrifice and play 3...Qe7 - still, after 4.Nf3 Q:e4 5.Be2 with 0-0 next white is much better, just by the following main opening principles - safer king, lead in development etc.
After g6 the queen captures on e5 with check and the h8 rock is lost as well - standard stuff by now.
A better move was 6...d5, the reason is simple - it gives c8 bishop control over f5 square.
And checkmate is coming.
Very good choice - the attacked knight after the retreat is attaking the bishop itself, winning time for development.
The knight is developed, a key central e5 square is controlled, kingside castling is coming pretty soon - what else could we expected from the opening move?
Increasing central control and preventing black from taking space in the center (e7-e5) itself.
Just keep developing!

And finally we managed to develop the kingside minor pieces and castle. The rest will be based on developing c1 bishop, moving queen to e.g. e2, rooks to d1 and e1, stabilize the d4 central pawn with c2-c3 etc.

Correct - preparing fianchetto with Bb2, which is going to put a long-lasting pressure on black's kingside, especially g7 pawn. One of the reasons why on b2 the bishop is so powerful is that there are no pawns on a1-h8 diagonal. The alternatives - like Be3, Bf4 or Bg5 are also perfectly playable, but on b2 the bishop is just more active and more annoying for our opponent.b3 with the idea of Bb2 is following opening rules (center, development, castle), as well it is in line with the move selection algorithm:1 - What is our opponent idea? He does not have anything direct,2 - Do we have any forcing options (checks, captures, threats). Well, actually there is an e4-e5, but this is not the best idea and it will be discussed later.3 - What is the worst placed piece? And here we go, Bc1, Ra1 and Rf1 are still undeveloped and this has to be handled one way or another.

Black puts another piece into the game, X-raying our queen. Currently, the only undeveloped unit in black's camp is Ra8, while on our side still three pieces (Ra1, Bc1 and Rf1) are out of the game - so we can assume black is 2 tempi ahead.Put the pawn on b3.

The only defence. Let's try to compare current position with the one at the beginning of the exercise:- e4-e5 push opened up the game, but it increased scope of black's pieces, not white's,- Re8 is active on an open e-file,- Bb4 is more active than on e7 (where it hits d6 pawn),- white still has 3 pieces out of the game, while after e.g. Rad8 black will be already fully developed.Again, RULE OF THUMB:Do not open up the game if you are undeveloped! Open positions favour better-mobilized army.

Correct - transposing into main position of a Vienna Game.Opening principles:CENTER - of course putting the pawn on a central e5 square meets the rule,DEVELOPMENT - by moving a pawn to e5 the diagonal for f8 bishop has been opened, so our move of course supports the development,CASTLE - assuming that the f8 bishop get some space, black is also one step closer to castling.The alternatives are d7-d5 (with some kind of a Alekhine-Scandinavian hybrid) or d7-d6 (transposing into Philidor or Pirc), since both moves fight for the center and are perfectly playable, but the text (e7-e5) looks somehow simpler.

Move selection algorithm:1 - What is white's idea? Looking at forcing options (checks, captures, threats), it is not that hard to see a Nb:d4 capture, so we have to address it somehow.We have 2 moves to choose from - either to develop a knight to c6 or put a pawn to c5.Actually, pushing a pawn to c5 is a stronger move - why?- both moves protect the d4 pawn and increase our control in the center, but:- by playing c7-c5, comparing to Nc6, we get a lot of space - and for example, Qa5+ immediately becomes a threat,- c7-c5 is a more FLEXIBLE choice - as Nc6 does not run away and we will be able to play it soon anyway,- but after Nc6 first, there will be no possibility to push the c-pawn in the nearest future, as the c6 would block it.
Correct, wasting no time!
Correct! Winning time for another pieces.
Just keep developing.
X-raying black queen - that was black idea. Later white will continue with Nf3, Qe2, castle kingside or queenside with a perfect mobilization of pieces.

Correct! Double attack on black's unprotected pieces (so tactical weaknesses according to our definition) decides the game, as black is not able to cover both attacked units.Move selection algorithm:1 - What is black's idea? He has nothing direct, so probably he would like to finish development with Nc6 or sth.2 - Any forcing (checks, captures, threats) options at our disposal?2a - In order to support your calculation and get the better feeling of the position, look for tactical weaknesses in opponent's camp - this is an additional point in our algorithm! We have already done it in the previous chapter (Ra8, Be7, f7 and h6 pawns).2b - Look for checks/captures/threats in order to define the candidate's moves in our arsenal:checks - Qg7, Qd4, Bd4 - nothing special,captures - B:h6 looks tempting (is a free pawn), with a mate on g7 threat, black has some defences like Bf6 or Bf8, but pawn is a pawn and we should seriously consider this move, but let's look further.RULE OF THUMB:As 2nd world champion Emmanuel Lasker said: "WHEN YOU SEE A GOOD MOVE, LOOK FOR THE BETTER ONE"!Threats:- we have e.g. Nf5 against the e7 bishop and Qg7 mate to come, but again black has Bf6 or Bf8,- we can try to use our info about the tactical weaknesses and try to take them into observation - Qf3 is a double attack on both a8 and f7, but Qe4 is even stronger, as both Be7 and Ra8 are attacked!Also, we can start searching for candidate moves before 2b step, just by looking at the tactical weaknesses and the way they can be exploited - so more geometry than actual chess calculation!

Correct! Exploiting the tactical weakness of the a4 bishop.It is much easier to find the solution if in the starting position you managed to spot that the bishop on a4 is actually a potential target (tactical weakness!).

Correct! Bishop on f5 is a tactical weaknesses, because it is attacked once (by a g3 knight) and defended no more times than attacked (once as well, by Qg6). So white's goal is to find the smartest way to increase the pressure on Bf5 - and this can be achived by a double attack - Qc5 threatens both taking on f5 as well as Qf8 with checkmate.(Recalling Metallica's album "And Justice for All" - pawns on a7 and b7 are also tactical weaknesses, as they are not defended, but I hope we everybody feel that there are not relevant in this position.)
The tricky part is to realize that the f3 knight is actually not defended, because of the pin down the g-file!
And black is a full rook up.
Everyone back, close to each other - just like Poland against Argentina!
This is the trick! And there is no king takes d8, as the king is on b8 instead of c8.

And white is still worse due to pawn structure, but the material is equal.The purpose of this example is to make us remember, that there is no magic formula in chess and it will be too simply (and sometimes too boring as well!) to play perfect chess just by answer a few questions to yourself - chess is a very concrete game and sometimes even the smallest detail (like king on c8 instead of b8) could change the evaluation of the whole position.
Perfect! The c3 knight was a tactical weakness - attacked once (by Qa5) and defended once as well (by Qd3).
And white lost 2 minor pieces.

Correct! The d3 bishop is actually a good one - he is walking on the light squares, so it is not restricted by the c3/d4 pawns. Pushing a pawn to g6 restricts bishop's activity on the b1-h7 diagonal and is in line with rule 2 which we've already mentioned:If your opponent is left with an active bishop, try to put your pawns on the same-coloured squares as his bishop walks.

Correct!We are obliged to put our pawns on the dark squares in the center (d4 and later c5), so before c5 is played, we are planning to exchange our in theory bad bishop (dark-squared bishop while the pawn chain c5-d4 will be also on dark squares).
Correct! Following rule 3, black is trying to exchange his bad bishop for the opponent's good one, which (after kingside castling) could be a very dangerous attacker towards black g8 king!

Correct! In this pawn structure (a so-called Stonewall), with most of our pawns on light squares (f5, e6, d5, c6), our dark-squared bishop is an active piece (as well as an imporatnt defender of weakened dark squares) and we should not allow white to play Ba3 (with the bishops exachange) under positive circumstances!

Perfect! Move selection algorithm:1 - Does white have some ideas? Nothing direct, so probably he will keep developing, Qc2 stuff etc., nothing we can do.2 - Any tactical blows in our arsenal? It seems there is nothing obvious.3 - So, let's look for the worst placed pieces - and this is actually clear, Nb8 and Ra8 are still waiting for the game and this is something which has to be addressed.- there is no Nd7 because the bishop is on d7,- Na6 is suspicious - the knight does nothing on a6 (away from the center), and even future Nc7 shift is hard to achive, because c4-c5 locks the bishop,- so we have to make a room on d7 for the knight,- and the best way to achive that is Be8, with the ideas of Nbd7 and Bh5 next - bad light sqared bishop outside the pawn chain!

This one looks like a safer option, as we are exchanging the knights (Nf3 vs Ng4) which activity is similar. But more important, we choose a knight capture just in the process of elimination:- how about B:e5? Let's follow the rule and compare the activity of Bg7 vs Nf3 - the dark squared bishop seems to be a much stronger piece, controling a lot of squares on the long h8-a1 diagonal, as well as defending weak squares on the kingside - h6, f6, g7 etc.After B:e5 N:e5 N:e5 white will definitely has a lot of compensation for the pawn due to unopposed dark squared bishop on e3 and weak dark squares in black's camp.

Correct - e3 is the most powerful square for our bishop:- it controls both wings (hitting both h6 and a7),- it increases the central control (over d4 square),- a good thing, due to h3 pawn we are not afraid of any annoying Ng4 jump.Why not B:f6?RULE OF THUMB:Before an exchange, compare the activity of potentially exchanged pieces!- following the basic chess knowledge, in an open position the bishop is better than a knight,- our dark-squared bishop is a GOOD BISHOP (it walks on dark squares, while the pawns in the center c4/e4 are on light squares),- by playing B:f6, we give up the bishop pair and we are left with a BAD e2 BISHOP! (it is light-squared, while pawns in the middle of the board c4/e4 are placed on the light squares as well, restricting the bishop).

Move selection algorithm:1 - What is white's idea? Any forcing (check/capture/attack) options? Nothing comes to mind, so white's intention is probably to caste long or short - there's not much we can do here prophylactically.2 - Any forcing options on our side? Not so much, only capture B:f3 (except the absurd B:d4), but as we already know - it's a shame to get rid of a strong light-squared bishop here.3 - So we're looking for the worst-placed piece. The king has not castled yet, the queen and the rooks are in the starting positions.Qe7 is a healthy developing move, the queen's best place is e7 anyway (flexibility!), and you can delay castling, waitingt for white to show his direction.However, there was nothing wrong with the normal short castling 0-0 either - the h-file is supposed to be open, but it seems that white does not have enough resources to strengthen the attack. Especially Bg7 is a strong defender, with no opponent (dark-squares bishop) in white's camp.

Move selection algorithm:1 - What is the opponent's idea? There's nothing forcing (checks, captures, threats) so he probably would like to complete his development - just that he has to spend some time on it, an immediate 0-0 is out of the question due to B:d7. So probably support the knight with Rd8 first, then 0-0 - some gymnastics.2 - Do we have any direct options (checks, captures, threats)? Aside from trades on d7 (which has been already discussed), nothing special we can do.3 - So we're looking for the worst-placed piece- Rh1 doesn't do anything special so far, but at least it's on a half-open lane, so if black goes 0-0 in the future, it might be useful there,- Ra1 is out of the game,- Ke1 - castling not done yet.So the choice seems relatively simple - we finish the development with 0-0-0 and play on with the advantage of space and advantage in development - and the opponent has to spend time defending the Rd8 knight after which we can, for example, push f2-f4 to gain even more space in the center.

And black achives a sufficient counterplay, and any exchange is to his advantage. White's attack has slowed down because they have to adapt to the opponent's actions in the center.RULE OF THUMB:Piece exchanges are (usually) in the defending side's hand - the fewer pieces involved in attacking the king, the lower the chance of success.

White stands better:- one pawn island (e+f+g+h) vs black's two (f+g+h; c),- c6 pawn is a weakness,- white rooks are active, attacking the weak c6 pawn,- both black rooks are passive, attached to the defense of the c6 pawn.RULE OF THUMB:If possible, block the square in front of a weak pawn (as in this case Rc5 does), so that the pawn does not go forward.THE PRINCIPLE OF TWO WEAKNESSES:Most often, one weakness in the opponent's position is not enough to win the game, as one way or another, the opponent is most often able to defend one weakness (as in the position in the diagram - black is passive, but holds). Therefore, in order to create a real winning chances as a stronger side, you usually have to open the second front.To sum up - although white is better, with correct play from both sides, the game should end in a draw (only one weakness in black's camp, which cannot be attacked further).
A typical example - thanks to the pin along the c file, white wins te c6 pawn and should win the game too.

Theoretically, the a2 is a weak pawn (it's a separate pawn island), but in practice it should not be a factor that affects the evaluation of the position.RULE OF THUMB:A weakness is only when you can attack it!In the position in the diagram, although in theory the d4/e4-pawns are not weak, in practice black can try to put pressure on white's center.
From the strategic point of view, this move is quite risky.

And white is left with weak pawns on a3 and c4.RULE OF THUMB:Pawns are strong when they are connected in a group, not separated!Therefore, the d4-pawn should not be exchanged. With the d4-pawn, the two connected pawns in the center (c4 and d4) are more an asset than liability and secure a space advantage, while without the d4 pawn, the c4 unit is nothing more than a weakness, a target which black can attack.Instead of d:e5, castling 0-0 seems to be a sound option, in line with the opening rules (center, development, castling).
Correct - since the c4 pawn was lost anyway, you should give it in the best scenario for yourself - i.e. forcing white to have a weakness.

And white was left with a weakened pawn structure. The position is more or less equal (although some great authors like Kamil Plichta from Poland or Srinath Narayanan from India provides a lot of useful advices for the white side on their Chessable courses) - black's pawn weaknesses are compensated by white's strong Bg2, which is clearly better than Bc8.
White gives away his extra pawn (which was lost anyway)
... creating a weak pawn on c6, additionally located on a semi-open file. Objectively, the position is even - white has the better pawn structure and black has a pair of bishops.
The backward pawn is the one on c5 - it is not isolated, but cannot be defended by its colleague from the b-file.
With the e3-e4 next and the pressure on the backward c5 pawn - doubling rooks on the c file is also on the agenda etc.

The position in the diagram is a typical isolated pawn position (IQP), which turned out to be unfavorable for white - because Black managed to exchange all the minor pieces, reducing white's dynamic possibilities and as a result making it easier to attack the d4-pawn.Black's plan:- obviously attacking the isolated d4 pawn,- placing all pieces on the d file,- if necessary, in case of some pin down the d-file, boost the attack with e6-e5.
1-0 White wins.
And it seems that the problem of the inactive rook will be solved - in a moment Rg1 with a pressure on the weak g6 pawn.In the next chapter, we will look for some opportunities for black.

Move selection algorithm:1 - Does white have any forcing options? (checks, captures, threats)? So far nothing special, but you have to keep in mind Rg1 pressuring the g6 pawn.2 - Does black have any forcing possibilities (checks, captures, threats)? Not really.3 - We are looking for the worst-placed piece. That's a tough one. The king is ok, defending the weaknesses g6/e6. The bishop is quite active (in theory it is a bad bishop, because we have pawns on white squares, but at least he is outside the e6/d5 chain). For the knight it is also difficult to figure something out - Ne7 is not possible, Nd8 is so passive etc. Rook? The only free files are f and h, but we have no objects to attack there.RULE OF THUMB:If we can't find a plan, let's look for the pawn breaks!

And thanks to the b5 break, black is left with a free pawn on the a-file. Here you can see the fiasco of white's plan - Ra1 will not be able to be active, because it will be forced to block the a pawn.Conclusion? The exchange of one pair of rooks in this position (Game Plan 1a) turned out to be advantageous for black, because the only white rook is forced to passivity.So what should white do? Avoid exchanging one pair of rooks in "Game Plan 1a". Then, while one white rook is watching the a-file passer, the other can take some active action.

- we avoid exchanging rooks (as we know from Gameplan 1b, exchanging is beneficial for black),- we don't care about giving up the h-file - it doesn't bring too many benefits to black, even after Rh2 the knight defends the g2-pawn,- we plan Re3-Rf3, with some problems for the black king.
As a result. one white rook is very active (f3) and participates in the attack, and the other is dealing with the a-passer.
And the white d4 knight dominates the black bad bishop, black has no obvious objects to attack or good-looking pawn breakthroughs - because e.g. f7-f6 resulting in weakening the e6-pawn etc.

Algorithm:1 - Does the opponent threaten anything (checks, captures, threats)? No.2 - Do we have any tactics (checks, captures, threats)? Nothing too special.3 - We're looking for the worst-placed piece - Bc8 has not been developed yet, so we're preparing to place it on a long diagonal, from where it will shoot at the weakened position of the white king.

1 - Does the opponent has any blow at his disposal (checks, captures, threats)? Nothing special, but Nb4 is an annoying possibility which we should avoid. Because, of course, we do not want to exchange the light-squared bishop for a knight.RULE OF THUMB:In the open position, the bishop is usually worth more than the knight.RULE OF THUMB:Bd3 is a GOOD bishop - because he walks on the light squares, and we have a pawn in the center on a dar square. And it is active on the b1-h7 diagonal, from where he can participate in an attack on the black king.
How to react with black?

That's the point, we create a theoretically weak pawn for white on d4 (because it can't be defended by any other pawn), which we could attack with Qb6 + Nc6 and in a moment Nh6-Nf5.If you want to take a look at the commentary on other, weaker options (c4, c:b4), back off and play them on the board.

Black's plan is to double the rooks on the d-file - but the question is - what's the point behind it? There is little to gain on the d-file, and the only weakness in white's camp - the f2-pawn - is heavily defended. Black should rather focus on his main assets (free pawns on the queenside) and push c5-c4.
If now black plays h7-h6, white might consider a weakened g6-square near black's king as a small success (which sometimes helps in perpetual check Qe8-Qg6 etc.).
And if black plays g6, he will be left dealing with a weakened seventh rank and an annoying soldier on h6.

... and in the case of a g:h6 capture, the 7th rank and the black king in general is weaker as well. According to the engine's assessment, Black's position is still totally won, but we the people are playing, not computers - we care about creating practical chances.
White uses the second of his assets in the position - the a-file.
Just play Qb5.
White rook entered 7th rank. Black's king can not feel comfortable.

Suddenly it turns out that it's the black who has to be careful. In the following movevs, white can play e.g. Bc4 or Rb7 (attacking b6 and e6 weaknesses) and even according to the engine the position has become even. And finally, after the game it was white who celebrated the victory: https://lichess.org/ZwkCrbwa#0CONCLUSION:Even in the worst-looking positions, try to indentify your assets and try to build a gameplan around them, which from a practical point of view can cause as many problems as possible for the opponent.

The position is better for white, it is easy to see it using 3 opening principles criteria:1) Center - it is underwhite's control (d4/c4 pawns), which also secures a space advantage,2) Development - white has two pieces developed (queen and knight), black has none,3) Castling - white is ready for 0-0 in the next move, black is missing 3 moves (because the whole kingside needs to be unpacked).In connection with above mentioned factors, the move ...c6 played by Black should be critically assessed - it was necessary to go for the development as soon as possible - even the simple knight move to f6 looks decent.
Again, suggest a move for black and go further to see the solution.
Of course, finally black has to start the pieces development and prepare to castle.
And again - suggest a move for black and go further to see the answer.
Be7 looks more solid - in order to castle as quickly as possible. Development, center, castling - the 3 principles of a successflull opening's strategy.Push d4-d5.

Although the engine is not a big fan of this move (as a refutation proposed Nb6 with the idea that the d5 pawn is now pinned), there is a clear logic behind it.RULE OF THUMB:If you have an advantage in development, let's open up the position!Opening a position increases the power of your (developed) pieces, it can be problematic for the opponent's king in the center etc.As mentioned earlier, Black had to maintain the tension (without opening up the position) with Nb6.

After opening up the center, black's position became really poor - the king is exposed on e8, Re1+ is about to come etc.Moving back to the starting position, it was enough for black to take care of the development of the kingside earlier - and there would be no such problems as in the example.

White's position is of course much better - secured by a material (pawn) advantage as well as the bishop pair. However, we have to play a move anyway :)Move selection algorithm:1 - What are the opponent's ideas? There are no forcing ones (checks, captures, threats), probably black want to castle next, but (at the moment) there is no way to prevent it,2 - Do we have any forcing options (checks, captures, threats)? Qb3 may comes to mind, but it does not win a pawn (b7, d5), as black has simple answer like c7-c6 or 0-0-0. Anyway - Qb3 is a decent option as well,3 - Look for the worst placed piece - and this one is actually very easy - Bf1 has to move in order to castle next and complete the development. As simple as that.

Move selection algorithm:1. Does the opponent threaten something direct (checks, captures, threats)? - it seems not.2. Do we have any tactics (checks, captures, threats) at our disposal? - also seems not - and Nf5 is a "one-time" trick, black will simply move away the rook and our knight will not feel comfortable on f5.RULE OF THUMB:Knights feel comfortable when they are supported by a pawns.3. We are looking for the worst-placed piece:- Ng3 may not be perfect, but he is a good king's defender (let's not forget that black has Rh6 and Qd7 aimed at our kingside, and the knight can join the party quickly - via Ne6-Ng5 or Ng6-Nh4),- Ra1 is still out of play, but it is difficult to guess which square it belongs to, because the files are closed - only the c-file is semi-open, but it is not obvious how to explain what role the rook on c1 would play. Pressuring the c6-pawn? It is well defended though.4. If we can't find a plan - let's look for the pawn breaks:- the e3-e4 break does not look solid - because it weakens the d4-pawn,- but preparing the b4-b5 break is a typical way of playing in this structure, called minority attack.MINORITY ATTACK:- Why "minority"? Because with 2 pawns (a and b) we will attack 3 black pawns (a, b, c)- Target of the attack? By reaching b5, creating a weakness in the opponent's camp (in case of c:b5 - the d5-pawn is weakened; in the event of allowing b:c6 - the c6-pawn is weakened).And Ra1 will be able to find a decent place for itself (b1 or c1).
From b1 the rook supports b4-b5 break.

Black temporarily prevents white from playing b4-b5, but it has everything in chess has it's price - at the moment black knight is not interested joining the kingside, which gives white some freedom as well.
Some kind of tempi Sg4-Se5-Sd3 stuff is coming.
Finally, the minority attack is finalized!
Thanks to the minority attack, black is left with the weaknesses on d5 and b7. On the other hand, white's pawn structure (one pawn island) looks impressive.
And white is going to grab the b6 or d5 pawn, black is not able to defend them both. Full game: Flohr - Euwe 1932https://www.chessgames.com/perl/chessgame?gid=1042371
And black is close to be checkmated.
The h3 pawn is going to be a "hook" in the future.

A strong move that attacks the main defender of black's king (Nf6), and on the other hand prevents black from playing the freeing e6-e5 (activating the c8 bishop etc.). It's also in line with our move selection algorithm - what is our opponent idea? The e6-e5 break. So let's prevent it. f2-f4 was a good option as well, although not as aggressive as Ng4.RULE OF THUMB:In London-like structures, if black manages to play e6-e5, he usually gets a very good play. The problem of a weak ligth-squared bishop is solved, some space is gained, etc.
And the rook elegantly entered the game down the h-file (so-called zero development - the rook has not made a single move yet and is already very active).
Multi-purpose move:- on the one hand, we still make sure that black does not break with e6-e5,- on the other hand, we attack the "hook" on h6 (there is some g4-g5 threat etc.).
1-0 White wins by checkmate.

The position has to be better for black due to his lead in development and the pieces placed towards the white's king (Qh5, Nf6, Bd6).Move selection algorithm:1 - What are the opponent's ideas? He has nothing obvious (checks, captures, threats), probably he will continue the development with Bd2, we have to also watch out for some potentially annoying possibilities like Nd4 (offering the queens exchange, which of course as an attacking side we have to avoid) or e4-e5 but it seems that nothing we can do,2 - Any forcing options for us? Ng4 sacrifice does not work, so nothing special,3 - Any piece we can improve? Our rooks are still somehow out of the game (primarily Rh8), so let's try to detect some place for it.- Re8? Looks active, but what's next? There is nothing to attack on the e-file, especially if we plan to attack the king,- Rf8? This one does not look well,- Rg8? The most logical option, placing the rook in front of white's king.So Rhg8 is definitely a candidate move, let's look further.4 - Any pawn breaks on our disposal? There is g5-g4, attacking the h3 hook! And what makes it even stronger, on above mentioned Nd4 (threatning queens exchange) we have g5-g4, speeding up the attack without the necessity of moving back the queen.So g7-g5, with the ideas like g5-g4 or Rhg8 next. Black has a very strong initiative.
Not allowing Ng4 - we can't allow black to trade the e3 bishop for a knight - because Be3 is needed to play Bh6, and trade black king's defender from g7!
The typical attacking scheem - the pawn goes to h5, the bishop goes to h6, then we open the h-file. Why not h:g6 first? Because after f:g6 Bh6 Black gets an additional defensive option Rf7.
We open the line h. B:g7 and then h:g6 is fine too - it's just the different move order.
After h:g6 there is B:g7 K:g7 Qh6+ Kg8 Qh8 checkmate.
Exchanging king's main defender.
Covering the h file is necessary, otherwise Q:h7 mate.
And black king is left without any defence.
In order to push h4-h5, the h-pawn does not necessarily have to be supported by the g4-pawn - because the sacrifice of the h-pawn itself (when black captures N:h5) also opens the h-line for the rook.
Having the h-file already open, we are going to exchange black king's defender.
g4-g5 and the exchange sacrifice after Nh5 is OK as well - but with Nd5, we directly challange the h7 pawn defender.

As a result, white created a b3 "hook" on the queenside. Keep in mind that we don't necessarily talk about a "hook" only when it involves weakening the position of the king. First of all, "hooks" are all about opening the lines and they can be anywhere, not only closed to the king.In this case, black's plan is to push b5-b4 and then hooking the b3-pawn by going for a6-a5-a4. The target of the attack? Placing the heavy pieces on the a-file, opening it with a4-a:b3, entering down the a-file and simultaneously attacking the weakness on b3. What should be white's defensive plan? At all costs, looking for the kingside (because the center is closed) counterplay - see the chapters about closed positions strategy.

Why Qf7 and not g6 or f:g4?- g6 creates a "hook"- white could play g5 and then push the h-pawn - h3-h4-h5, opening the h-file and continue the attack,- fg4 hg4 allows white to get a strong mobile pawn group - and since black wants to attack on the queenside, it is good for him to keep the kingside relatively closed.

And this way white has no counterplay at all - he will not be able to open any line on the kingside, because black has no "hook" there (pawns g7 and h7 are in one line). Removing the tension from point f5 is highly beneficial for black.
Imagine white pawn is on b2, not b3 - there would be no "hook" and black would have zero chances to open any line for the attack.
With the Ra7 next, entering with the rook to white's camp using the a-file with a complete black's domination.

Back to the roots - the move selection algorithm:1 - What is white's idea (checks, captures, threats)? There was a Ng5 threat, attacking both the h7 (with checkmate) as well as the e6 (with the fork Rf8+Qd8) - so somehow we have to prevent Ng5 jump one way or another.I found the h7-h6 risky - it creates a "hook" in our camp, and for example after g2-g4 we have a very unpleasant choice - whether to allow g4-g5 (attacking the h6 hook) or take on g4, which makes d3 bishop so powerful, opens the g file etc.

Move selection algorithm:1 - What is our opponent's idea? He has nothing forcing, but probably he plans to castle. Any ways to prevent it?2 - Any tactics (checks, captures, threats) at out disposal? Qa4+ and Bb5+ quickly come to mind and it's easy to see that black has no good way to meet those checks (Nd7 gives up the bishop after B:g7, while after Qd7 there is either Bb5 and the queen is pinned - if white goes for Qa4 - or just B:d7 if white goes for Bb5+) and has to move the king, losing castling rights.Why Qa4 is more accurate than Bb5? Because it brings another piece to the game.

Preventing black's development. Additionally:- white's bishop is more active than Bg7, which is restricted by white's pawn chain c3-d4-e3,- B:g7 K:g7 is good for Black - he gains space, communication between rooks etc.
The white queen is joining the defence through the 2nd rank.
Or Kg1 Qg3+ Qg2 and we avoided the perpetual as well.

Move selection algorithm:1 - What is the opponent's idea? He has some potential jumps like Qh6 or Qf4, but at the end of day it's very likely he will try to continue the development - and natural moves like Be2 or Bd3 comes to mind. Do we have any power to prevent it?Rg8 places the rook on an open file and the bishop can't move due to R:g2. g3 with the idea of Bg2 is not possible at the moment as well, because of the f3 knight. White is facing some coordination issues.

White wins no matter who has the move, though for clarity's sake we'll give White the move here. The key feature of the Lucena is the extra pawn on the 7th rank, one square away from turning into a Queen. Also, both Kings are joined in battle, with the white King in front of his pawn and the enemy King as close to the area of battle as possible. Clearly, White needs to do two things if he wants to win: - Move his King off of d8 so he can push his pawn - Promote the pawn to a Queen Simple goals indeed, but is it really that easy? Of course not! The problem is that white's King is blocking his own pawn and, at the moment, the black King and Rook are preventing it from getting out of the way. Since the black Rook can't be budged, White must make the black King give ground
Black has no intention of giving up his control over the c-file! Without a King, White can't hope to win

Hello, and welcome to the study! In this study I aim to go over basically everything about a very common opening known as the queen's gambit. Before we go any further I will ask you to click the heart bellow, to inspire me to create more studies like these, Please enjoy the study! Thank You!
1.D4 is the start to a very deep and incredulous opening known as the queen's gambit.Let's start with black's most natural and common possibility which is D5.

With this move black is basically trying to accomplish the same thing as white, which is to control the center and develop the minor pieces, the same thing with white's first move being e4, rather than d4. The only difference about the queen's gambit is that the next move is c4, which seemingly hangs a pawn, after all that is what makes it a gambit.
Black normally takes this pawn.
Here white has many possible moves, like e4 or nf3, but there is actually a trap that black can fall for which starts with white playing e3 here.
Other popular variations :

This is putting a lot of pressure on black, all because they were to greedy and wanted to keep the pawn, in this position black often plays c6 to defend their b5 pawn, because if they played a6, then white would play Axb5 and black's pawn on a6 would be pinned to their rook on a8.
white first captures black's b-pawn. Here, black should not recapture, but play e6 instead, and try to survive a little longer.

Because black was so greedy, the light squares are extremely weak, thus the rook got trapped. Please notice that going back to move 3 if white had played e4, this trap wouldn't have worked becuase, the diaganol controlled by white's queen would be blocked by their pawn. Please also notice that black is not losing a full rook here since they can play nc6 or bb7 but white will win at least a piece.
Other variations :

black blocks the check with their bishop which allows black's queen to defend their rook. Even though white isn't going to win a rook, they are up a full knight and have a very easy game from here, especially since black's pawns on the queen side are very vunerable and cannot be easily defended, once there is an endgame.
Here we come back to the queen's gambit to explore another variation, known as the queen's gambit declined.
Here black is declining the gambit, they don't want any trouble so they don't take the c4 pawn. Here white should simply continue with their development.
White develops their knight and if black takes on c4 white plays e4 with tempo
Here, it is fine to take on d5 and simply trade pawns, if you wanted you could continue with a move like nf3 or bf4.
Now it is a completely equal position and both players have an interesting game.
In the previous chapter we already saw what happens if black declines the queen's gambit with e6, but there is another way for black to decline the gambit, which is c6.

This is known as the Slav Defense, and is very interesting. You will also be able to see some variations with the Slav in future chapters as BLACK. Going back to our position, white can take on d5, or can develop more pieces with moves like nf3 or nc3.
If black takes, white anyway plays e4.
white continues, to develop, and e3 is very nice because it makes way for the light squared bishop to defend the c4 pawn.
The game is pretty much equal and white has a nice position and perhaps a little more development.
Queen's Gambit Excepted.
Black is trying to un-double their pawns, but white isn't going to take
Now white takes on c4
White gives away the bishop to deflect the black king from the queen. Kxf7 is forced
White has just won a queen and has a +13.3 advantage!!
This is known as the queen's gambit excepted, old variation.
This Nf6 move happens a lot more often when you play the queen's gambit against higher opponents, it is one of the many safe ways black can play after excepting the gambit.
White gladly takes the pawn back. Material is now back to equal.
White keeps on developing.
Now white plays Qa4+
Now black has made a mistake, this bd7 move allows qb3, c6 was better.
White is winning at least a pawn. Please note that this is kind of a less common trap and it doesn't win a queen or something like that, but this one MIGHT happen in someone's game.
This is a very common way of declining the queen's gambit as black. (see chapters 2-3).
white develops....
black develops....

Black castles. so far things are going pretty normal.
white sacrifices their knight to trap black's queen!
The queen is trapped.

Now white has won a queen and it is completely winning. This is also called the Rubenstien Trap. Please note that you don't need to memorize all this, because it isn't likely to happen in your games, this is just a fun pattern, that can be used in other parts of the game.
Nimzo-Indian Defense.
Black tends to Fianchetto the light squared bishop, and later on bring a knight to e4.
This f5 move might seem bad at first but it helps defend black's powerful knight and prepares a very strong attack on the king side.

Black is soon going to castle, and have a nice game. Though black didn't get an attack they sometimes have to be okay with that. In the next chapter There will be an example game, where black DOES get to attack with this opening.

black carries out the plan.
black is already starting to start their attack.
The knight is now well supported.

Black castles, which helps the kind get safe, and has Ne4 coming.
black takes their time, and then strikes, when white is the most vulnerable.
This looks very nice for black, in the Nimzo-Indian this night is so called a 'monster knight' since it is very strong on the center square.
This move is not exactly to protect the knight, but more of an attacking move, since this allows black to play something like rf6 and rh6, to start the attack.
This move isn't very common but is possible, perhaps white doesn't see the danger ahead....

In the Slav Defense black builds a pawn chain from b7 to d5, and continues normally with moves such as Bf5 and Nf6. Here we will look at a couple variations that could happen.
Other variations :
Black just takes back.
Here we reach a completely equal position, both sides have a very nice position, just to show, the game could continue, something like this :
The knight might be coming to e4, or The rook on c6 might be coming to c2.... This is the kinds of positions you can get when playing the Slav Defense.
Here a very high rated chess, player Topalov, is playing the Slav defense against The current world champion, Magnus Carlsen.
Black has now entered The Triangle Slav.

Also, as A slav defense player, you should know that Black's light squared bishop, is often not very useful in the opening, since the e6 pawn blocks their development, That dark squared bishop is usually more useful in the endgame.
black makes an interesting choice here, and rather then playing the more common Bb4, pinning the knight, black decides to Fianchetto the Dark Squared Bishop and pressure D4, latter on.
Now The bishop is more open.
White is trying to break up Black's very strong pawn chain, but Black instead of taking plays Qd6 which is much better.
This makes way for the bishop and helps activate Black's Knight.
Black decides to trade off, white's knight in order to prevent it from coming to c5, And perhaps from coming to e5 too.
Black opens the file.
Now black's knight is really powerful.
Black offers a trade of queens, if white were to trade, then black would have a better endgame since they are up a pawn.
A nice little tactic by black, if Qxb3 White loses a rook.
White takes on c8, now black must take white's rook on c1, otherwise they just lost a whole rook.
Now this is an endgame
Black temporarily gives away a pawn, but it was anyway very weak, and would have been captured in a more complicated way.
Material is now equal.
please note, that The queen can't stay on the D-file because there are some Bxf2 tactics, for example :

white stops the checkmate.

oh no! Maybe white is winning!

Here we have a nice Queens Gambit Declined.
Black takes anyway!!
And now white is forced to block the check with their queen. White was to hasty to take black's queen and now at the end of the variation they will end up down a piece.
Black has just won a knight! Please note that this trap is actually kind of common, and it is likely to happen in one of your games! I hope you enjoyed this trap, it is my personal favorites!
Here we will look at another variation white could go into, called the London System, which is when white plays 2.Bf4.
In this opening white makes the same kind of pawn triangle that black did in chapter 13. This is also why the pawn triangle in the Slav defense is sometimes called a reverse London.

Most of the time black tries to attack white's pawn triangle. Here white should just calmly castle, but if you want to be more agressive you could play H4, and attack on the kingside (see the next chapter).
White has a small advatage here, and white also has more center space, perhaps one day the knight on f3 can go to e5.
Black's pieces are badly placed. White can continue with H5 or Qh5, and have a very fun game.

Queens Pawn Game : Zukertort Variation

Hi guys! I'm Aiden from Hong Kong. This study is dedicated to learn more about the d4 opening.I'm not that good at chess, and only have a rating of 14xx FIDE. Therefore this study might not be suitable for you if you have a 2100+ rating in this website. It's mainly for studying together as a community. Of course, you are more than welcome to tell me your feedbacks to help us improve. Let's start now.d4 starts with the Queen's pawn, and controls the centre. Black usually responses with either 1...d5 or 1...Nf6. We'll take a look at that in later chapters

This is the Queen's Gambit. White 'sactifices' the pawn in order to control the centre. It is a very common way to start the game for white. Here, black has three main responses, which are dxc4, e6 and c6. We will take a look at all three in the next chapters.
game starts with the Queen's gambit.
c6 is the Slav defense, a very popular response to our opening. I would personally recommend the exchange variation, but of course, you can develop your knight to f3.
3.cxd5 is the exchange variation. It aims to get a symmetrical position, in which white can create threats.
black recaptures.
Bf4 develops the bishop. Here, the optimal response is 5...Bf5.
After both players trade bishops and develop their pieces, connects their rooks by castling, the opening is over, and white is definitely not worse in this equal position.
Again, we begin with a Queen's gambit.
Black accepts the gambit.
We support d4, and attack the c4 pawn
We capture the free pawn.

Game continues, as both sides develop. White might end up in an isolated pawn position, but it is difficult for black to capture it.Less people go for the QGA nowadays, but it's still important to learn the main ideas. In sample game 2, i will show you a very famous game played in the QGA.
e6 is the Queen's Gambit declined.

4. cxd5 enters the exchange variation. Of course, it's completely fine to play 4. Nf3 and continue the game. Yet, we can eliminate majority of variations by taking the pawn, and we can memorize a few less lines.
Black recaptures. If black recaptures with the knight with4...Nxd5 ?!, e4 forces another exchange on c3 and white gets a huge centre.
both sides develop their bishops.
Bd3 develops a bishop.
Nge2 indicates that white is going for an attacking game
Here, white can castle kingside and be very solid. Then, white would rely on a minority attack on the queenside to try to create winning chances. However, i would recommend the interesting 0-0-0.
In this opposite side castling position, both sides fight for a devastating attack, game continues.
Nf6 enters the Indian game. Here, white could go back to the traditional c4, but I recommend the 'Tromp' attack (Trompowsky opening).
2. Bg5 enters the Tromp. It puts pressure on the f6 knight. Here, black has three main replies. Ne4, d5, and c5. We are first looking at 2...Ne4.
We retreat the bishop to safety. This also threatens f3 to kick the knight and grab the centre with e4.
f3 kicks the knight. Here, black plays Qa5+ to prevent white from developing the knight to c3.
d5 locks the centre and prepares to finish the pawn chain with e4.
Qb6 attacks b2, and we play the seemingly weird Bc1. White prepares to play e4 next.
Game continues, and white tries to fight using the extra central presence.

In the first bishop chapter we looked at what to do when you have bishops in your inventory and how to utilize them in the middlegame. Here we're looking at some more bishop play, but this time we're going to see a PLAN being executed as well. Notice the imbalances. 1. White has the two knights; Black has the two bishops. 2. White has no open files; Black has 2 open files (b and g) Black is going to want to turn these imbalances into decisive advantages. A PLAN presents itself.

Straight up the middle. He is coming into the center. Observe this; there are a ton of CENTRAL PAWNS on this board. When you have bishops, it's best if there is NO CHANCE of any central pawns in the baord- that way those bishops can cut all the way across that board. So the 2nd part of black's plan is to RIP OPEN THE CENTER. He's going to force all central pawns to be destroyed. This is what you want to do if you have bishops.
By just exchanging a few pawns, now we can see the center opening up a little bit! :)

And look at that diagonal!! Look at our bishop comin' right down here to the rook. We're threatening his rook. The dark-squared bishop is going all the way to the king. THIS is the kind of OPEN FIELD that we're looking for to play in with our bishops. This is what you WANT TO DO with this imbalance. We're going to make our bishops STRONGER than his knights.
And now you'll notice that we're attacking his OTHER ROOK in the corner. So we've got two rooks attacked. He is going to lose one of these rooks. Now watch what white does next. A beautiful move.

If YOU have knights, this is what you must do with them. Unfortunately for him, it's too little too late, but look at where that knight is. Look at the outpost. An outpost is a PAWN that SUPPORTS THE KNIGHT. That knight has a radiating influence. It even blocks the queen from taking the rook.
However, my bishop still has the option of taking his other rook.

Black is doing pretty well- he's activated his bishops and he won the exchange. However, the rest of the plan hasn't been put to use yet. Another part of the plan should be how to GET RID of white's centralized knight. You should be striving to improve your own pieces, and also to LIMIT your opponent's!
We push our pawn to c5, and we force the knight to move. We're using the STEINITZ RULE which says the best way to defeat a knight is to TAKE AWAY all the active outposts that it can place itself on.
The knight is still in our camp, spreading mayhem and confusion. We're gonna chase him off again.
Now the knight is on the rim and is doing nothing. We've successfully implemented that part of our plan- to render white's knights ineffective.
Of course we take the free rook. :)
He brings his queen up and destroys our central pawn, he's attacking OUR rook, and he's closing in on our kingside which is extremely uncovered- we haven't castled yet.
We should have castled earlier, but we didn't. So HERE we castle. His queen's getting close- hold the phone- that's enough. We're gonna castle out of danger- that's important to do.

White is offering the exchange of queens. Black notices that white has a huge pawn majority on the kingside, and if he exchanges the queens, that pawn majority could mow him over. Black decides to keep his lady and put pressure on white's pawn majority.
The final step of our plan: Put our rooks on open files. Attack the queen directly.

We want the other open file! xD Be greedy! We have BOTH open files RIGHT DOWN THE CENTER, leading into the kingside. We have our queen putting pressure, a diagonal with the bishop, our king is safe, and we have two very powerful open files. We're going to win this game because WE'VE STUCK WITH OUR PLAN. White, on the other hand has ONE knight on an outpost. His queen is doing nothing. xD
The game has been over for several moves.

This is the kind of chess to play. You reach a critical position, you analyze the board, the imbalances and the features, and then you create the plan BASED ON what the CHESS BOARD is TELLING YOU to do. In the meantime, we explored what to do if you have bishops. Rip open the center and place them on long, powerful diagonals, along the way RESTRICTING the ENEMY KNIGHTS.
This is a game that I recently played where the ROOKS come into powerful play. This game especially promotes the idea of putting your rooks on the 7TH RANK.
I'm using a HYPERMODERN theme here. This means I'm controlling the center with MINOR PIECES and not with pawns.
The e6 move blunts the diagonal of white's bishop.

My development is VASTLY SUPERIOR to my opponent's. I have SEVERAL pieces of my army developed that are being very constructive and centralized. White's SINGLE poor bishop in the corner is in the cage and isn't having any influence AT ALL.

I IMMEDIATELY grab this central file. This is what you MUST DO with rooks. Put them on OPEN FILES-that way they gain very strong power. There are two bishops in the way, but powers can move off the file, unlike pawns.
Gonna see what he does with his bishop.
He's still keeping that diagonal.
I establish a very good knight in the center and open up my c-pawn.
I establish a strong pawn chain. The beautiful thing about this is it COMPLETELY SHUTS DOWN white's bishop and knight! They're extremely restricted. I have the advantage.
Since I have the better development, I'd like to exchange off HIS developed pieces.

Black's position is VASTLY SUPERIOR to white's. My pieces are well coordinated, developed and centralized. The knight controls the central squares, my queen and bishop control diagonals, I have my wonderful pawn chain restricting white's pieces and my rook is placed on the CENTRAL OPEN FILE.
I exchange as to simplify the position and to double white's pawns.
His knight can jump into c5 at any time and fiddle with my position in disgusting ways. In order to prevent this...

Now I bring my OTHER ROOK into this game. Look at my position. I am fully developed. My pawn chain is well placed, my knight and bishop are being constructive and my rooks are CONNECTED and placed CENTRALLY. I'm feeling really good about this position.
I'm going to exchange. This gives him weaknesses, allows my knight to jump in AND it OPENS UP my rooks on the open files.
Where do rooks belong? Open files. Where do rooks want to go? The 7th rank. My intention is to pull my OTHER ROOK to the 7th rank as well. This is going to COMPLETELY WIN THE GAME for me.

I bring my second rook to e2, and LOOK at the POWER OF MY ROOKS on his 7TH RANK. I have my opponent so overwhelmed with the power of my rooks, (PLUS the fact that I have a knight as a backup :) ) and I clearly have the winning position here, BECAUSE of my rooks on his 7th rank. My opponent resigned at this point. I hope that game illustrates to you the devastating strategy of planting your rooks on open files, and then moving them to your opponent's 7th rank. That gives you a VERY HIGH CHANCE of winning your chess game. :)
This chapter shows you how to use PASSED PAWNS. It also shows us some more play of how to use rooks on open files, and what NOT to do in the opening.
White is using this time to develop his forces.

Because of the nature of black's opening, he hasn't put his knight on f6 contesting the center. White is now allowed to throw up a HUGE pawn center. White has more CENTRAL SPACE, and we'll get into this as the game progresses.
Black's bishop is a completely unprotected piece.
Black puts his knight on the rim to cover his bishop. He's not in a very good position here. Notice how pushing pawns and moving your queen makes it more difficult to coordinate your army well.

Black's queen is trapped. Black made the mistake of bringing out his queen with everything else behind, and he's lost his queen already. That's why it's SO IMPORTANT to bring out your OTHER PIECES FIRST. Don't charge with your queen in the front.
Not happening. Not this game, man. No way.
Before white kicks the knight away, he wants to grab the open file to black's king. This is what you MUST DO with rooks. Put them on OPEN FILES.
Now white kicks the black knight away with the Steinitz rule.
Instead of opening the f file, black pushed his pawn and closed it. That was an incorrect move. Black should aspire to create open files for HIS rooks.
Black's knight has a LITTLE area to roam around in.
White's gonna go for a checkmate.

Black takes the pawn, which I believe was an ERROR. The reason being, he opened up white's g-file for HIM. That was an ERROR. If he would have let white take his pawn and then he retook back, black would have had the open a-file. As black played it, he gave his opponent the open file. DON'T DO MOVES THAT HELP YOUR OPPONENT!
Now at this point, white has had his space advantage. His e5 pawn is a PASSED PAWN. Three more moves and he can queen. Well when black pushed his pawn, white can take him EN PASSANT...

Yup. Black took white's queen with his bishop! So now material is even, however... White has been doing everything he could to make his advantages WORK... And they have! White has WONDERFUL central space, yes?White has a very beautiful open b file, a very beautiful open g file, and two VERY POWERFUL passed pawns. Even though he has lost his material advantage, he has the superior POSITION, and he utilizes this.
All rooks aspire to reach the 7th rank.
White has two very powerful passed pawns... USE THEM!! This is where the energy is... Push it! Those passed pawns will completely win the game for white!
Black has a passed pawn as well...
White starts to force the exchange of rooks.
And now what's white's next move?
White wins by force. His pawns are unstoppable.
This game showed how to utilize your passed pawns and when to exchange the rooks.
White has a checkmate threat on c7 with his queen and knight.
Black retakes with his queen as to guard the a5 square.
White's knight is very powerful. It's preventing checkmate on g2, guarding the queening square of black's f pawn as well as blockading black's d pawn.
Black moves his queen BEHIND his passed pawn to prepare its push. Rooks and queens belong behind the passed pawns to give them support as they march.

Look at the central power of white's knights. These knights control so many squares, it's incredible. Meanwhile, white's queen has radiating influence in all directions. This is what you want to do with your pieces- make them as influencial and pull as much of their weight as possible.
Black's pawn is nearly queened, but white has the square covered well.
GRAND centralization of the queen. Even in the last stages of the game, CENTRALIZING YOUR POWER is THE thing to do. White's queen radiates power in all directions.
Before you go on, can you try to figure out the winning move? ;)

Brilliant queen sacrifice!! Smothered checkmate. Most people favor the queen because she's the most powerful piece, and she can be very lethal. You shouldn't make too many moves with your queen in the opening, and instead use her so that she can influence the board in a powerful way.
In this chapter we see a game where white takes a material risk (and regaining it later on) in exchange for a tremendous initiative against black's king.

At this point white's main advantage over his opponent is his HUGE PAWN CENTER. White is going to want to prove it is indestructible and have it restrain the enemy pieces. The OPPONENT of the pawn center ought to do EVERYTHING HE CAN to DESTROY that pawn center.
White is expanding his center and putting pressure on black's bishop.
White goes ahead and continues pressing for more central space with his pawns.
Shirts uses his central pawn to create some weaknesses in black's camp. If black takes white's bishop, he can take either black's bishop or f7 pawn, both leading to favorable positions for white.
Now black's king can't castle. White has sacrificed his bishop, and in exchange he will have a very offensive attack against black's open king.
Bad move! This allows white to get a material advantage AS WELL AS have a king attack.
Now black's king is wide open and white has the better exchange. White is clearly in the driver's seat.
Trying to block white's queen in the corner.
White's queen is pretty closed out from the action, but white still has the initiative.
White must continue pressuring black's king in order to not lose his opportunity.
Bringing the rook right up onto that outpost. Putting pressure on the pawn and the bishop.
White continues pushing. He can eliminate one of the defenders of black's king.
White continues with his central thrust, attacking black's king again.

White has a problem, however. He doesn't have his ENTIRE ARMY working together. His queen is stuck in the corner. AND because white has pushed his e pawn, his rook is unprotected. He either has to protect it or move it... But white has to get his queen back in the game! Do you see a move that allows white to free his queen?
Check to the king and he forks his queen. So black HAS to take with his pawn...
White has finally brought his queen into the attack and he has a winning position.
This is a pretty good move- he's just cutting the chessboard in half with that WONDERFUL bishop, and threatening my queen.
Continuing to improve his position with a discovered check from the rook.
Black needs to keep the pressure on white's king or he's going to lose instantly.
Now black covers the checkmate square.
Now white is threatening to take the g4 pawn instead.
Black can successfully get rid of white's queen.
So now we're down to rooks! Plus black's poor knight that hasn't moves once.

Correct. This is the best retort. Black occupies a key central square (e5)and snarls at another (d4). Additionally, Black can now develop both the queen and king-bishop. In responding this way Black steals the initiative from White, who futilely wasted his first move by moving the king-rook pawn.

Correct. It's usually a good policy to move the king-pawn out two squares if the opportunity arises. It aggresses the center and prepares the activation of two pieces, the queen and king-bishop. And with f3 obstructed by a pawn White loses one of the best ways to assail Black's e5-pawn, a knight development to f3.

Correct. This strikes at a central square (e4) and establishes a beachhead on another (d5). Moreover, the diagonal line of Black's queen-bishop is now cleared, and to a starving bishop White's g4-pawn looks like a tasty morsel.

Correct. Black's direct assault on the center (d7-d5) usurps space and opens paths for the queen and queen-bishop. It also arms Black with the option of advancing further (d5-d4) against White's c3-knight. This would probably lead to a loss of time as White's beleaguered knight scurries to safety. It also makes a statement. By being bold and direct and different, Black announces his unwillingness to draw. He wants more!
Correct. Although this is a symmetrical response, it's still a very good move that attacks the center, gains space, opens lines for development, and establishes a physical presence at the frontier.

Correct. This is called the Sicilian Defense (1. e4 c5) and has become a staple of the contemporary tournament player. Although its only immediate contribution to development is to clear the a5-d8 diagonal for Black's queen, it strikes at the heart of the center(d4) with asymmetrical fervor. It also prepares to exchange the c-pawn for White's d-pawn once White advances the d-pawn to d4. This would result in Black having more pawns remaining on the central files than White (Black would retain the d- and e-pawns, White only the e-pawn). Generally, if you have more pawns in a region, you have an excellent chance to wrest control of the region. And what better place to have dominance than in the center?

Correct. It strikes at the center (d5), it clears two splendid diagonals (d8-h4 for the queen, and a3-f8 for the dark-square bishop), and it supports the advance d7-d5. Its name is the French Defense, and its chief liability is the blocking in of the c8-bishop, which French Defense enthusiasts typically refer to as the "problem bishop."

Correct. This is called the Caro-Kann Defense (1. e4 c6), and like the Sicilian Defense (1. e4 c5), clears the a5-d8 diagonal for Black's queen. But it differs from the Sicilian in that instead of striking at d4 it supports the counterattack d7-d5, which opposes White's e-pawn. The expansive Sicilian tends to be played by those who enjoy sharp fights, while the compact Caro-Kann appeals more to those striving for solidarity and position play.

Correct. This is an excellent developing move, activating the king-knight toward the center. Meanwhile, it deals with White's primary opening plan, which is to establish a classical pawn center (two center pawns, on the e-and d-files, aligned on their own 4th rank). With Ng8-f6, White is unable to advance his e-pawn two squares for Black now controls e4.

Correct. This is a fine retort, producing what's known as a double-queen pawn opening (that's where both sides start the game by moving out their d-pawns two squares, so that each obstructs its enemy counterpart). Black's reply also meets head on White's plan to advance the king-pawn to e4. Now, if White were to play 2... e4, Black would take White's pawn for free, 2... dxe4.

Correct. I prefer this move. It develops a knight toward the central hub and it prepares kingside castling, which is more usual than queenside castling because it tends to be quicker. In addition, it's not as committing as 1. Nb8-c6, for it obstructs the f-pawn, not the c-pawn, and it's far less necessary to retain the option of moving the f-pawn early in the game. There's always an element of precariousness in moving the f7-pawn (or the f2-pawn for White), for in so doing Black exposes the king to possible danger along the e8-h5 diagonal. Moving the c-pawn, however, merely uncovers the queen along the a5-d8 diagonal. The queen can fend for itself by guarding the line it already occupies, but the king is totally vulnerable to distant linear threats.
Correct. This establishes a foothold in the center, seizing the square e4. It also clears developmental paths for the queen and queen-bishop, while carrying no real weaknesses.
Correct. The thrust of Black's king-pawn to e5 is good standard fare. It concerns the center, it builds developing capabilities, and is consistent with the plan of early kingside castling.

Correct. This is preferable to 1... g6 here, even though on e5 the king-pawn becomes a target for White's dark-square bishop. But Black has resources, and he can hold his e-pawn and the early space edge it confers, though White still has the initiative by virtue of starting with the first move.

Only the ones you want to play or/and learn.
the best way to play as black, is to accept the pawn and give it back later. White on the other hand has a big variety of moves to development.
The main move. If black accepts the pawn, white can develop with tempo, so black should not capture but rather defend the pawn.
Black keeps the pawn and a decent position, but has to develop the bishops.
Immediately going for the center.
Getting control of the center too.
Black gains more space and a pawn.
Now after trading the queens, the King in the center isn't that much of a weakness.
Black now can either castle Kingsside and play 13. Rfd8, or castle long side, which is a lot more aggressive.

Good replies for Black against 1.d4 are d5, Nf6, e6 and c6. The Budapest Gambit starts with 1. ... Nf5
If White hopes for a quiet game, he will try to play the Queens Gambit here by playing c4. If however White plays 2. Nc3, Black should be careful, as that is the start of the Jobava London system.
2.c4 now invites black to play the Budapest Gambit, 2....e5! Other good moves for Black are e6, d5 and c5.

White declines the gambit with d5. Black now has a few options. Stockfish 10 recommends Bb4+ as the best move for Black. However, we are first going to look at three tricky lines that flows from 3...Bc5

Bc5 puts immediate pressure on f2 and in some lines Black will sacrifice a piece on f2. Note also that Black is 1 tempo away from castling, whereas White is 4 tempi away from castling. Black already has a huge lead in development.White now has a few options on what to play. The usual move for White in this position is to develop his B to g5, pinning (a relative pin) the Black knight to the Queen. However, 4.Bg5 is a mistake. The best move for White in this position is Nc3. Let's see what happens when White plays B g5.
Ne4 is an interesting move. It leaves the Black queen en-pris and in most cases White will snap up the queen without thinking. This would of course be a major blunder because of Bxf2#!!
5.Be3 is of course White's best move to try and mitigate the damage caused by playing Bg5 in the first place.
As mentioned before, Black is 4 tempi ahead in development; now is the time to attack!

Recapturing is not exactly a forced move, but if White does not recapture the B on e3 he might just as well resign. Black is on the attack, he still has a major lead in development and should keep the attack going. Hence....
White has only one legal move here; g3. So he plays it.

Black can now decide to keep attacking in two ways: he can drop his Q back to h6 attacking the undefended pawn on e3, or he can play Nxg3!, threatening to win the exchange. We shall go for the more aggressive line, and grab the pawn!
If White takes the N with hxg3, the Rook on h1 is dead.
Now the evaluation is already -4.7. White can resign.

This is the starting position of the Budapest Gambit accepted. Black has two main options here. His N on f6 is under attack and Black has to move it. The two main moves are Ne4 and Ng4. Stockfish 10 recommends Ng4.In the next chapters we shall first look at Ne4 and thereafter Ng4.
White must now tread carefully. The Stockfish recommended move for white in this position is a3, but would you play it as White? But of course you say, so let's play it!

d6 is a standard move for Black in this position. Black wants to recapture with the B on d6 and will be ready to castle. Note again Black's huge lead in development.If white does not take on d6, Black threatens to take his pawn back by playing dxe5 next, trading queens with a better game for Black.However, 5.exd6 would be a mistake. Let's look.

By this time, White can feel the pressure in the lack of development. Black is ready to castle, and White's whole kingside is undeveloped.The best move for White is Qc2, but will you play it and further neglect your kingside development?Logic suggests that White plays g3, Bg2, Nf3 and 0-0. Let's see how that works out for White.

Unsuspecting, behind in development, White feels obliged to take the N. He should in stead have played Qa4+, but as you will see that line is also not good for White.The stage is now set to win the White Q by force.
With an evaluation of -7.6 White can resign.
We saw in the last game that a3 is the best move, but White still lost his Q. Let's say he tried 4.Qc2.

Black, again with it's huge lead in development decides to attack, rather than defend the N on e4. 4...Bb4+. White's best reply is to block with the N on c3. Nd2 looks to do the same...block the check and attacks Ne4.
Now it's time for Black to defend Ne4 with d5.
This is a developing move that frees the light square B on c8 and defends the N.White will probably take this pawn en-passant.
Once again Ne4 is in need of protection, so Black develops his B to f5 from where it defends the N on e4. Note also that Bf4 x-rays Qc2!!

So Black develops his B to f5 from where it defends the N on e4.Note also that Bf4 x-rays Qc2!!Note also that the Black B on b4 is undefended and it looks like White can pick up a free piece by playing Qa4+.
No more free B for White. White's kingside is still completely undeveloped.White does not care, he decides to attack Bb4 one more time with a3.

Now Black could just simply trade the B for the N on d2, followed by picking up the pawn on d6 with Qxd6. Note that at this stage, the computer gives Black already an advantage of -3.2!In the spirit of the Budapest Gambit, Black decides not to liquidate, but keep the pressure up. Black plays 8...Nc5!
Brilliant move! The Queen is trapped with only one square to go...back home!White now realised that he is going to lose d6 for nothing, and tries to grab a pawn with a tempo on the Black Q with dxc7.
Now both queens are en-pris. Instead of taking the pawn with Qxc7, Black sets the trap with Qe7!! Remember, the White Q is still trapped and only has one square to go...home.

Remember, the White Q is still trapped and only has one square to go...home, but Qd1 would now be a huge blunder. White should accept that his Q is lost and take a pieces for it by playing axb4.If it's a short game, White would play Qd1 and if it's a long game, White would probably resign.

This is the starting point of the 3...Ng4 lines in the Budapest Gambit Accepted.White has a few development options now. Stockfish recommends for White to play 4.Nf3. Let's see what can happen if he plays 4.Nc3, a natural looking move.
Black can now immediately take back his pawn with Nxe5, but the N on g4 is not under attack, which allows Black to get another developing move in.
In this position, the Stockfish recommended move for White is exd6, exactly what Black wants.

Note that Black is now ready to castle kingside. White on the other hand is 4 tempi behind! This is a huge lead in development for Black.So what would you now play for White? Stockfish recommends to get on with development with 6.Nf3.If White in stead decides to kick the N on g4, he falls further behind in development.

Black now sacks his N on f2, threatening both the Q and the R. Believe it or not, but the best move for White in this position is to sacrifice the Q on d6 by playing Qxd6, getting two pieces for the queen.Most people will however feel obliged to take the sacrificed N on f2, not seeing the mate in 4.
Ke3 was best. Now mate is unstoppable.
If White tries to attack the N with his Q by playing Qd4, he is asking for trouble!
Black develops his pawn to d6. This also opens up the light square B which is now defending Ng4 against the Queen's attack. Black is also ready to recapture on d6 with his B.
Bxd3 leaves the g pawn unprotected. This is however a highly poisonous pawn. The best move for White is Qe4+. Let's see what happens if White get's greedy.
And the Queen is almost trapped! The only move is Qg5, but this loses material for White.
Black wins a full R with an evaluation of -5.7!!

Black develops his N with tempo to c6, countering the threat on d6 with his on threat on the White Q.Black is ready to castle. White is 4 tempi behind before he can castle. White now loses a further tempo because he has to move his Q to safety. The best move is Qc4, from where you could develop your light square B to Be6, gaining another tempo on the Q.
White has to move the Q again, this time to c2, losing a full rook on h1. If however White is careless and accepts the N offering, he loses his Q.
Black can now either play Bxc5+ or Bg3+. Stockfish prefers Bxc5.
This is the Stockfish preferred line and is cleaner. Both Bxc5+ and Bg3+ wins the Q.
This computer line is better as you pick up the pawn on c5 first. The evaluation now is -7.3!!!

4.Nf3 is White's best move in the position.Black has two good moves in this position. The one, an attacking move with Bc5, which is the Stockfish preferred move, and Nc6, which we will look at in the next chapter.In the spirit of the Budapest Gambit, black develops with an attack!
4...Bc5 puts pressure on f2 and threatens Nxf2. The best move for White here is e3, but we will look at it later.In this line, we shall look at 5.e4.
5.e4 is a blunder, because now Black can sacrifice on f2 and Nf2 is indeed the Stockfish recommended move.In another line, Black plays Nc6, developing the N.
Let's look at the computer line for Black with Nxf2, threatening the Q and the R.
Defending the B and freeing the light squared B.
With an evaluation of -2.3 Black is better here, being the exchange up.
Here Black quietly develops his queenside N to c6, attacking the e5 pawn for a second time.
White decides to defend the e pawn for a second time.
Black develops with a tempo on the K!

Nd2 was better. Black now has the opportunity to give White doubled pawns, but rather decides to set the trap in motion. We will look at Nd2 in the next chapter, is that move has it's own inherent dangers.Note that Black is ready to castle, whereas White is 3 tempi behind. It's time to attack the K in the centre.

Qe7 loads the bases against e5. So far White tried desperately to cling to the pawn he won in the opening, thereby sacrificing his development.The computer suggests as best move for White, Rc1. Not sure a human will play it.Black is now ready to take on e4.

With his lead in development, it makes sense for Black to attack in the centre. White should liquidate on e5.If White tries to get cute with something like Ng5, the N will be kicked until he has no escape.
The only available square for the N is Nd2, but that would be a blunder. The best move for White is h3.Let's look at the blunder....
As mentioned in the previous chapter, 6.Nd2 is White's best move here.
Qe7 is a very dangerous and trappy move.Note that the White king is completely boxed in by it's own pieces ant the Black Q is staring at him down the barrel so to speak.
a3 is a mistake...Black can ignore it as it poses an empty threat.
Black takes his pawn back and threatens mate in 1. If White blunders now, it's game over.axb4 is a blunderNxe5 is best
In the Ne4 lines we have seen this move a few times. Black puts pressure on e3, opens up the light square B and is ready to recapture on d6 with his dark squared B with a major lead in development.
Now the Q and R are under attack. What to do?
Black can now either play Bc5+ or Bg3+. Both wins the Q.
This is the Stockfish preferred move.
The move 4.Bf4 is just a move order difference which transposes back into a mating line.
Setting the trap. White should play e3 to avoid the trap.Black is ready to castle. White is 3 tempi behind.
Attacking the B.If White instead tried h3 to attack Ng4, the result would be similar....
Moving in for the kill. Ngxe5 works too. Again, White needs to play e3 to give the K breathing space.

The only move. As we will see, it is also a good one. Controlling the pawn is easier once the knight stands in front of it. Now the knight can manoeuvre at both sides of the pawn. It is easy to see that Black cannot create trouble anymore
The right move. As we said, the knight is transferred to a side of the pawn
This allows a draw straight away,
A superb move, very easy to find if we know that, when facing a 7th-rank knight's pawn, the knight cannot succeed unless it stands in front of the pawn.
The knight enters the right circuit.

The knight remains inside the right circuit, that is, h2-fl-e3-g4 and the black king cannot drive it away. Draw.----------------------Conclusion: The knight draws against a 6th-rank rook's pawn if it can stand in front of it. If the knight just controls the pawn's path, it needs to enter the right circuit to draw, that is, for the hi-corner, g4-e3-fl . From the f3-square, the knight fails.

(Analysis diagram 3.6 ) The black king seems very close to the pawn, but things are not that easy when he tries to come closer. The knight has set up a barrier (the marked squares). To cross the barrier, the black king must give up the pawn. To go round it, there are two possible routes: d4-e5-f4 or c2-d1-e1-f2. Both allow the white king to come closer. It is interesting to note that the essential (and solid) part of the barrier are the d2e2-e3-e4-squares, which form an L-shape.
Just in time! The white king can occupy the f2-square.

mateThe winning sequence can be more complicated, for example, if the knight occupies another square; however, if this happens, and we are familiar with the ending, it is always easy to find the correct winning path
