mate----------------As we have seen, in a normal position the queen wins against a 7th-rank pawn (even more so when the pawn is on 6th rank or even further back). However, in the next examples we will see that there are exceptions due to these two factors: A) Stalemate themes. B) The queen is hindered by her own king.
The point. The black queen must move to lift the stalemate and then the white king will come out of the h8-square, thus threatening with promotion again.

An important position to know.-------------------------------------Analysis diagram 4.5Despite having a brand new queen and the move, White cannot avoid being checkmated because his royal couple is poorly placed. Conclusion: In order to win against a 7th-rank rook's pawn, the strong king must be just two steps away from any of the two key squares: (here f7 or g6).
The queen starts approaching the pawn in the fashion we know.

Therefore, the stronger side's king has just one move to reach the key square g6. onclusion: In order to win against a 7th-rank bishop's pawn, when the defending king is on the 'right side' (near the corner), the stronger side's king must be one step away from one of the two key squares, g6 or e7.

and after promotion comes checkmate.Let us see what happens if the stronger side's king is on the other side of the board.

the correct defender must "abuse", of the stalemate defence again. Otherwise he is lost!

Welcome to my chess study of the Exchanged Caro Kann or ECK for short.The ECK is probably the most easiest way to handle the Caro Kann, why? Wellit lessens the theory and it consolidates white position aswell. There are two type of ECK players in here, one is people who plays the exchangedvariation because they do not have the exact repertoire to meet the Caro Kann so they decided to stick to their e4 e5 principle. hey try to replicate the opening, to try and make it similar to e4 e5 even if its the Caro Kann. The other is the ones that wants to cut of loads of opening homeworkand theory and try to keep the position simpler compared to the other Caro variations and at the same time try to achieve an improvise London System against black with the Horwitz with the c pawn missing. Ive played the ECK a lot of time but I prefer the Advanced Caro Kann, Two Knights Caro Kann and of course the Classical way of playing the Caro Kann. To be honest Ive stopped playing the ECK with the white pieces since it gives black the opportunity to develop with ease. Black's position remains as flexible as it would ever be and by the way many people have been telling me that theECK is probably a very good opening against the Caro Kann and even a handful of people Including Bobby Fischer employed it and had a great success in playing it. The Bronstein-Larsen Variation is the most aggressive way to play against the Classical Caro Kann. First and formost black weakens his kingside and voluntarily makes a double pawn but in exchange of a dangerous attack on the kingside. The g file is open and further play would be met on the kingside or on the center.
The main line in here is c3 in which of course supports the d pawn.

Qd5 is the main move that is often played in here. Well the idea behind Qd5 really depends on white's choices of play. In particular with the help of Qd5 black can easily shift his queen to h5 or even g5 in case of an attack on the kingside. In case of c4!? Well Qa5+!

Rg8 is the main idea in the Bronstein-Larsen Variation. Of course Rg8 creates chaos and potential attack on the kingside. Black's queen could easily be shifted to h5 or g5. Attack with h5! Is even possible.
g3 of course to counter the attack on g2 with the rook but in exchange black would keep on attacking white's kingside
Notice how black's queen was able to shift easily to support the assault on white's kingside!

This is what I like about the Bronstein-Larsen Variation. it reminds me of the Stafford Gambit but better since black is not committed to sacrifice a pawn in the opening and also quite flexible in development.

This is the Advanced Variation of the Caro Kann. The Advanced Variationof the Caro Kann is one of the most dangerous and challenging to playagainst. First of all white gains spacious advantage. White also has enough initiative on the kingside to launch a devastating attack against blackjust as can be seen on the French Defence. I recommend the principled and classical way to handle the Advanced Variation of the Caro Kann. Abbreviated as the ACK. Black gets to maximise his bishop on f5. Black gets a lot of counterplay on the queenside aswell. In the French Defence the LSB isoften a problem since it is a bad bishop. Black struggles to put out the LSB on the French Defence. Ive played the French Defence and I know the theory behind it. Sometimes in the French Defence black has to voluntarily double his b pawn just so he can get rid of the LSB in exchange for white's bishop or knight. Black do not sufer the same fat as the Advanced variation of the French Defence.
Thus, this is the classical way to play this, the ECK will be met withthe principled and classical Bf5! In that case black solves all his problemon the LSB.
Nf3 is the most classical response for white. White would eventuallycastle kingside and then develop his bishop pair aswell. There are othersidelines as well covered in here such as the move c4?!
Black locks his position by having a very solid pawn chain around in hispostion. Black is already doing well in terms of defensive and positionalplay. Black gets to be on offense in the middlegame.
White swaps of LSB right away resulting in a less complication position.Black gets to fight back towards the center right away with the move c5 andthen castle kingside.

I like the move Nd7 in case white launches an attack on the kingside. Itwould be useful since the Knight on d7 can be reinforced to form a fortressafter Nd7-Nf8 adding another defender on tthe h7 square.

The Tal Variation Named after Mikhail Tal Himself, this move is usuallyassociated with the opening trap of the LSB. There are many combinations ofsacrifices in here so I recommend the move h5!

h5 immediately occupies the g5 square, this restricts white from makingfurther progress on the kingside with the pawn storm. Plus the idea of themove e6 to create weaknesses around the kingside would not work since black will just capture with the bishop!

e6 solidifying black's pawn structure (and also transposes into a mainline)Qxb2!? is quite risky and offers white feasible counter play against black queen side since the b file would have been opened for white's rook to take advantage of.

Other options for white is the heavy theoretical c4! Which in this case isn't covered in this course because it would have been too long! However to make it up to you this is covered in my other Caro Kann course (Non-Interactive) So feel free to browse through the Advance Caro Kann in here! (To find the Tal Variation with c4!? Simply go to chapter 4 - Advance Variation - Time Stamp is with e4 c6 d4 d5 e5 Bf5 h4 h5 Bg5 Qb6 Bd3 Bxd3 Qxd3 e6 Nd2 c5 c4!?)Now if you don't want to study this long theoretical variation and would prefer a less theoretical line but sound. Simply skip this chapter and move to Chapter 35 where instead of c5 Qa6! Is instead played.
Black should exchange white's light square bishop, of course white would decline! Well if thats the case then black should exchange bishops in the next move!
Simply exchange bishops, with no fear of a kingside attack! (Keep in mind black should not castle kingside since this would leave black's king vulnerable)
End of opening preparation, black can start throwing a minority attack on the kingside.

g4! Immediately strikes the center and of course expanding on the kingside aswell. This extended pawns are quite useful in the near future because white would proceed with a devastating kingside attack. The only problem is what if the attention shifts and black is the one whos attacking? huh?
White would usually further harass the light square bishop. In here obviously white is planning to trap the light square bishop with the move h5!

h5 is needed because white is further going to expand on the queenside. As necessary in here white would usually castle queenside and attack black's king if h6!? is played instead of h5! Black has to sacrifice a pawn if necessary.
Now what must black do? Black cannot leave his bishop alone on g6 since it would be taken by white's knight and also it would further deteriorate black's kingside!

Sacrificing the pawn is necessary if black wants to fight for the initiative. Doesn't matter of the h pawn is gone. Its actually beneficial for black since the h file is now open for black's rook! Other than that the h pawn would heavily be pressurized in the future. Even now the h pawn is attacked by both the rook and the queen once the knight leaves.

White would ultimately shift his interest in the center. Keep in mind that the exchange of pawns in the center is necessary for white because of two reasons. One the knight on c3 prevents white from stabilizing his central pawns thus leaving him to forcefully exchange pawns. Two, if white doesn't exchange pawns then black would simply take the d pawn with cxd4 and the advantage is left for black.
A necessary move to supress black's attack on the center. Loosening up the grip eh?
White is forced to exchange bishop for queen just to loosen up black's pressure on the center.
Now the threat is d5! And black would be winning!
Qf3 is forced because of the d5 threat. The only good move which holds on for white!
The only good move, Be4? Nxe4! Well 0-0-0 is the only good move!

Black's pressure is so strong that I highly doubt that white could even defend and play on in this particular position. The d file is dominated by black, white's king is stuck. White's kingside is weak and so on.

I recommend the principled and classical way to handle the Advanced Variation of the Caro Kann. Abbreviated as the ACK. Black gets to maximise his bishop on f5. Black gets a lot of counterplay on the queenside aswell. In the French Defence the LSB is often a problem since it is a bad bishop. Black struggles to put out the LSB on the French Defence. Ive played the French Defence and I know the theory behind it. Sometimes in the French Defence black has to voluntarily double his b pawn just so he can get rid of the LSB in exchange for white's bishop or knight. Black do not sufer the same fat as the Advanced variation of the French Defence.

The Scotch game is one of the oldest openings, idea is to immediately try and contest the center.The first time the moves e4 d4 were ever played was by Napoleon Bonaparte (!!!), at least in Danya's Chessbase database search. The veracity of the games are disputed, according to chess historian Edward Winter Napoleon's games may have been made up as a propaganda tool.Why is it called the Scotch? In 1824, several games were hosted in the city of Edinburgh by members of the Edinburgh chess club against the London chess club where e4 d4 were played many times. It was common for these types of games to be played.

Black should prepare to castle queenside (long) as black's kingside pawn structure is damaged and white has some threats on that side of the board.
Further centralizing the bishop, more effectively pointing it at the white's king.
Putting the bishop back on a central attacking square.
Black stops white from playing a6 by playing it themselves.
Trapping white's queen and unleashing a discovered attack
0-1 Black wins by checkmate. ... checkmate.
Black should take control of the center and support that center by developing minor pieces.
Simply supporting the center pawn.
Black continues to develop, ignoring white's passive moves.
Forcing white to give up this pin.
Defending the pawn and forking square.
Danya plays a5 to demonstrate prophylaxis. Black directly stopping white from playing b4.
White continues to try and play b4.
Developing the knight with tempo and opening up c6 for the pawn to dislodge white's knight.
Another game where black should respond by occupying the center.
Following the plan of taking control of the center.
Black chooses to close the center. Note white's knight is poorly positioned. White would really like to play c4 to attack the base and undermine black's pawn chain.
No need to trade and allow white to develop the queen. Again black supports the center with tempo.
Black calmly continues development.
By taking with the pawn, white weakens their control over the e4 square.
The f pawn to stop white from castling.
Should black immediately take the pawn?
No, black can delay taking the h pawn and draw white's king further into the open.
This is the Italian opening, emphasizing good opening principles. Making moves that control the center and develop minor pieces.
... after the exchange black's kingside pawn structure is damaged and gives white Qd3.
White chooses to follow through with controlling the center with pawns.
White choosing to allow an open center since they are slightly better developed than black.
Black chooses to open the center up and trade some material.
White more or less ignores the knight and continues developing. Also nice that the bishop defends h2.
"Jeez relax." - Daniel Naroditsky Nov, 2020
Building the battery to attack the pawn.
Defending the pawn and preventing the queen from being overloaded as the only defender of the light squared bishop.
Looking to castle long as the kingside files are half open.
White isn't attacking the knight yet because taking the knight would hang the h1 rook.
Black chooses to get out of the way immediately.
Black weakens the g5 square. Are there any tactics that this enables?
Yes! Black's queen is x-rayed and white can take advantage by "sacrificing" the knight.
No need to take the queen just yet, white has a mate.
Defending the pawn and developing.
Black just takes anyway and blunders the knight.
Black pinning the knight to the king.
Unpinning the knight and developing the light squared bishop.
Sticking to the plan of completing development and getting the king to safety.
By blunting black's dark squared bishop and offering an exchange. White is more than happy to trade material as white is up material.
What piece should white take with?
The knight! White opens up two attacks and, again, isn't afraid to trade into an endgame up material.
White offers the trade while developing the rook to an open file.
White continues to grab material.
Black's plan is to occupy the center in light of white's passive opening.
Should black close the center of the board?
Both are okay, in this game black chooses to close.
White attacks the base of the pawn chain.
Black defends by intending to replace it with another pawn.
Black continues developing in the face of white's passive moves.
Where does the light squared bishop belong?
White no longer has the option to play h3 so black's light squared bishop has free reign over the g4 square.
Can black defend the light squared bishop with tempo?
Again, black is okay with giving up the pawn. Literally all of white's minor pieces are sitting on their starting squares!
Opening up the position, now on the queenside.
Sacrificing the bishop to fully leverage black's developmental advantage.
Further attempting to rip open the position.
White attempts to bring some defenders to the king, giving back the material.
Black bringing the last piece into the game, Danya said this is not the best move but it is actually engine approved. Turns out the engine agrees that you should develop to convert winning positions!
Black has a nice tactical idea here to win the queen.
First forcing the king onto the same rank as the queen.
And then distracting the only defender of the queen.
White moves the same piece twice in the opening giving black tempo to continue developing.
Black has built up a nice battery here, but the discovered checkmate attack can be easily stopped.
Instead, black goes for the g2 pawn.
White's pawn is pinned by the so white must give up the rook to stop checkmate.
Oops. Maybe white will give up the queen instead.
Start of the King's Indian Defense.
Giving up control of the center to develop pieces into positions that attack the center from a distance.
How can white threaten the e4 pawn?

Attacking the sole defender. Not a typical KID move it does illustrate a key theme. One thing to note is that comparing this to the main line, there is a bishop on g5 vs e2 which creates a potential pin that would materialize if black played e5.
... losing the pawn due to the pin on the knight.
Temping to retake here immediately, but there is a better move.
Ruining the structure of white's kingside.
Ideas of building pressure on the d5 square to challenge the bishop.
Executing the idea of attacking the bishop.
Black is not worried about this threat as it would allow Bxc5. Black would then have a bishop pointed at white's king.
Removing the queen from defending the pawn.
Trying to trap white's light squared bishop.
Danya miscalculated c4 here so instead of trapping the bishop and hanging the knight black instead...
... plays a simple developing move to strengthen black's position.
0-1 Black wins. Pawn forking the minor pieces.
Start of the Philidor. In the Philidor, white has ideas of developing rapidly into the center.
Weird move, but doesn't offer any concrete threats so white continues to develop.
... white expands on the kingside instead.
Blocking the influence of white's bishop. Note that black's knight is the sole piece supporting the c4 pawn, how can black remove the defender?
White has chances due to development advantage.
White is forced to take the knight or be mated.
Forced mate now possible with the bishop controlling the h7 square.
Now black has a way to win a minor piece.
Bishop seems like it gets away, but...

... white loses a minor piece in the exchange due to the bishop effectively being trapped.This looks like an ugly pawn structure for black, but black has more than enough compensation being up a full minor piece.
Can black castle here even though the bishop would be left hanging?
Yes, because the bishop is protected by pinning tactics.
Removing the defender from the bishop.
Could develop the knight to either space.
Black wants to play e5, can black play it now? White is threatening the hanging pawn.
Defending the knight while supporting the center with tempo.

Note that white has played h3 which has left a weak square on the kingside. Development is important, but it is also okay to move a piece in the opening more than once if you can identify and exploit a deficiency in your opponents position.
This allows black to stick a knight on it while also creating threats on white's king with the queen.
Defending the e5 knight so we can play Ng3.
Forcing white's queen back due to threatened mate in 2 thereby allowing black to play Qh4.

0-1 Black wins by checkmate. This is why these openings are dubious for beginner-intermediate players. They violate many of the opening rules and give principled players a lot of attacking opportunities that must be precisely defended.Again, this mate is made possible by the underdevelopment of white's pieces allowing black to build an overwhelming attack into the kingside where the structure was already weakened by the choice in opening.
How do we solve the problem of the hanging d4 pawn?
Preparing for the opening of the e file while tucking our knight away.
Working towards completing our developing with material advantage.
Centralizing the knight with tempo.
White has the option of playing Nf6 now that black's queen no longer guards the square.
However, white can opt for sticking to the usual plan of creating a battery and attacking black's fianchetto'd bishop.
Noting here that the check given by Ng5 opens up the f file. So how do we open up the f file to make a check with a discovered attack possible?
Sacrificing the bishop so the discovered attack is possible.
Priming the "open" Sicilian, by allowing the c and d files to be half open.
Black chooses to play the Kalashnikov variation, weakening the d6 and f6.
Targeting the other weak square where white can outpost the knight.
Transposing into the Sveshnikov, all opening theory up to this point. We would like to keep this knight outpost on d5...
So we can pin black's knight with the goal of eliminating it.
With ideas of redeploying the knight.
Still the main line of the Sveshnikov.
Note the b5 pawn is weak, how can we undermine it?
Offering opening up the a file which would allow white to deploy the rook.
Now allowing the bishop to be deployed to c4 to support the knight.
A nice "glue" move, further supporting the bishop and preventing Qxb2.
White exploiting the overloaded rook on f8 by given a check and discovered attack.
We would like black's king to be on e7, is there a way white can force black's king onto that square?
1-0 White wins. Yes, the only square left for black's king is e7 now allowing white to win the queen.
Looks scary because of the discovered attack on h8.
Stopping the discovered attack. This may violate rules on moving kingside pawns, but it serves a specific purpose in this line to eventually prepare e5.
Now black can play e5 with tempo.
Now black has a nice pawn center.
This looks scary for black, but at the moment white has no credible attack against black's king and black retains strong control over the center.
Black can continue to develop, attacking the hanging pawn.
Could take and open up the c file, or push the pawn down the d file.
Seizing more space in the center with ideas of taking even more space.
Two possibilities to capture. Black should calculate to figure out which one is better.
Forcing the trade of queens. This is good because black has control of the open file and up material.
Ideas of creating an isolated pawn on f4.
Now black has connected passed pawns.
2...Ne2 is sort of weird since it obstructs the bishop, but it's theoretically okay.
Black has a slight development lead after white plays the somewhat passive 3.c3, how does black take advantage of this?
Opening up the center by attacking white's e4 pawn. Also opening up development possibilities for the bishop.
Continuing to expand in the center.
White's move is bad here because it delays development of their pieces. There is no need to trade at this time.
White doing what black wants which is to open up the center with a pawn exchange.
If you don't believe Danya, just look at the computer eval! Even on material, but black is much better here due to lead in development and attacking opportunities against the un-castled white king.
Now black wants to continue opening up the center by removing the d-pawn. There are two ways of accomplishing this, should we use the rook or the bishop?
White is now supporting the d3 pawn twice, how can we continue to apply pressure to it? Bf5 is no longer possible because white's knight covers it.
Which we can play immediately, threatening trading queens with a fork.
The bishop has a nice x-ray against the queen, how can we prep an attack?
Ideas of a discovered attack with check to win the queen.
White plays into black's hands and allows us to support the pawn with an equal trade.
This also has the consequence of opening up the c file where black now has easier access to attack white's king.
Calmly developing our own pieces while breaking the pin and threatening a discovered attack of our own.

Black has an overwhelming advantage here with all of their pieces in the game and in some way or another pointed at white's king. White's pieces are scattered and uncoordinated leaving them with a poor defense and no counterplay.

A nice Alekhine's gun with three pieces controlling the file. Named after Alexander Alekhine, former Russian World Chess Champion. Alekhine apparently died under suspect circumstances, officially "choking on a piece of food".
Sacing the rook to open up the king for a checkmate.
Not a great move because it obstructs the bishop from developing.
Preparing d4 to occupy the center with pawns. Also opens up the queen to attack two pawns.
Pawn center achieved. We are not concerned about the pin, white's bishop is in a nice position pressuring the g7 pawn.
Supporting the pawn while developing a piece.
Black wants to ruin the pawn structure, but this is not too concerning.
This allows an additional pawn to support the center. Additionally white has the lead in development, maintains the bishop pair, and has an uncontested bishop looking down towards black's kingside.
Another passive move from black, giving white time to develop.
Continuing development as black continues to play passive moves.
The king here is okay in the center because it is safe. Black has no threats, and white still has the option to castle kingside if needed.
1-0 White wins by checkmate. Note that the rook that was developed holds the key square which allows for checkmate. This is a result of disciplined development of pieces to good squares.
Start of the Pirc defense where d6 and g6 are played. This grants white control of the center. Key idea for white is to castle queenside to attack on the kingside.
Preparing queenside castling and creating a battery to trade bishops.
Long term idea here for white is to start an attack against the kingside by opening up the h file. There is no need to trade bishops yet, instead using this move to start a pawn storm.
We could immediately play h5, but the g pawn is hanging so...
White now has the option of opening up or closing the center. Given that white is attacking kingside, which does white want?
At this point, white's attack has been blunted so now white should look to develop the rest of their pieces.
Shutting down black's attempt at counterplay. Unfortunately black's counter attack will be too slow.
Forcing black to either move the defending queen or allowing the g file to be opened up where the rook will go.
Attempting to correct the previous error to allow Rdg1
Key mistake was going after the wrong knight, should have gone after the e4 knight with Re1.
White threatening Re1 to pin and potentially win the knight, however black has the simple resource d5 to simultaneously defend the knight and attack the bishop.
Executing the aformentioned d5 defense
bf5 is an option to reinforce the knight, however, it is more important to unpin the knight even if it results in losing the pawn in the exchange.
Black should be looking for ways to develop and dislodge the knight.
re8 is great as it develops the rook and attacks the knight
Note that trading here is good for black as black is up two pawns
Simple developing move while up material.
Preparing c3 to create a passed pawn.
Continuing the main line of the Ruy Lopez
White threatening to remove the knight defender on c6 and take the e pawn.
Continuing down a common line in the Ruy Lopez
This is why Bb4 is not as good of a move as it seems, this allows white to reposition the knight from the queenside to the kingside with tempo.
Removing one of white's most active (and annoying) pieces.
Getting the dark squared bishop onto a nice diagonal with tempo attacking white's queen.
Here black would like to develop the knight to a square but which one? Unclear which is better so...

... instead of choosing which square to choose to put the knight on just yet, we develop the rook first and wait to see what white does first. This allows some flexibility in black's play.Black also has a nice fork available with the Qa5.
Now we are okay with trading since black is ahead in material.

Danya does not recommend the Scandinavian for beginner players because the main drawback of the Scandi is black only has developed the queen after moving it multiple times in the opening. It requires an understanding of when to break opening principles which beginners do not possess. Basics first, then add the twists.
A nice move to support the knight and skewer the c7 pawn.
Grabbing space on the queenside and solidifying control over the b5 square, possibly as a space for the queen.
Critical move to find here with the aim of getting the knight to c7 to attack the trapped rook.
While apparently hanging the b5 knight, simultaneously gives white control over the critical c7 square while also delivering an attack on black's queen.
Strong move by black, attacking the bishop while also threatening to trap the knight after Nxa8.
This forces a retreat from white.
Could take with either rook or pawn, which one?
The rook to preserve the pawn structure and prepare an attack.
Sacrificing this pawn is fine to open up the position on black's king.

Alapin Sicilian, named after Semyon Alapin, a Lithuanian chess master from the early 20th century. The first person to play the Alapin was William Poupart (sp?). Semyon was the 4th person to play it in recorded chess games.The purpose of the Alapin is to control the center by preparing d4. Black would like to prevent this.
d5 doesn't directly prevent d4, but allows black to contest the center
Again, white attempts to prepare d4 while tightening their grip on the center
Played to prevent white from executing their plan of placing a pawn on d4
Three pawns are also being attacked.
Taking a pawn and more control of the center.
When up material, do not forget to develop! e6 opens up the diagonal for the dark squared bishop.
In general trading is good when up, but not the only way to win. Players get in trouble when going out of the way to trade and accidentally weakening their position.
Fine to trade if it falls into your lap.
Theoretically forcing the queen trade because white has no way to defend the a3 pawn AND get the queen to safety.
There is an opportunity to trap the queen. Qc5 is the obvious idea, but there is a better move...
... and this forces white to exchange the queen while also allowing black to develop a piece into the center.
Again, trading when convenient without weakening black's position.
Defending the rook and forcing the favorable rook trade for black.
Defending the passed pawn with the goal of dislodging the rook using the light squared bishop.
Executing the plan and dislodging the blockading rook.
Same idea here as we push the passed pawn to convert a material advantage into a win.
Same idea here, creating passed pawns to promote. There are also ideas of moving the king around to play for checkmate immediately, but it's easier to just push pawns.
Developing with tempo attacking the queen

Idea for black here is to pile on pressure on the d4 pawn both by directly attacking it and indirectly by attacking the pieces defending it. Ideas of castling long will add another piece attacking along the half open d file. This line requires precise play from white.
For white, the theory here is to immediately attack the c6 knight even though Bxf3... g3 ruining the pawn structure is threatened. The other moves will result in losing the d pawn.
Idea here is to preemptively unpin the pawn.
Black continues to apply pressure by pinning the knight
Supporting the d4 pawn, pawn is not hanging because black's knight is pinned.

... this exchange which traps black's bishop and ruins the pawn structure. Allowing the bishop to be trapped here is a CRITICAL error.d4 holds for now, but we would like to defend it with the c pawn which requires...
fxe3 which allows white to support d4 with tempo
Black attempts to attack, but weakens the e5 square which would make a nice outpost for white. White is also able to get away while landing an attack on the queen.
Danya likes white's position here because black's bishop is suck in the corner and hard to get into the game. Black would like to activate the bishop by opening up the diagonal with the pawn.
White is now better after black trades off their most active pieces on the kingside.
Black attempts to capitalize on the weakened pawn structure but...
... white easily defends with the king while also unpinning the pawn
... which is simply stopped with Rd2
The bishop is finally free, but too late.
Start of the Austrian attack, idea is to build a big center by developing pieces to support the center.The Austrian was first played in 1850 by John Cochrane.
White has some choices in how to develop the bishop.While Bc4 looks like a good move to develop the bishop, it runs into...
Yes, the bishop is blocked, but this follows the idea of the Austrian which is to support the center.

Which pawn to take with? f pawn would open up the bishop and get ideas of a kingside attack ready. However, Danya does not like this line and would normally play dxe5, though he does note that either are fine.
Bishop positioned to overprotect the center pawn.
Ignoring the hanging pawn for now to continue to build up pressure on the kingside.
Attacking the rook so we must move it first before continuing the kingside attack.
Key move here, immediately taking Bxh6 results in...
A move that serves two purposes 1) defending the knight so the queen can attack, and attacking black's queen with tempo.
Forcing black into losing the exchange.
White's king here is in an uncomfortable spot, one idea is to trade queens to lessen the disadvantage of white's king being in the open vs black's king which castled and is, for the time being, safe.
Allows white to force the queen trade by "fork" attacking and defending with the knight.
Start of the London system (though, sort of a different move order than the usual 1.d4 2.Bf4).
Two options here, trading bishops or dropping back to g7.
How to undermine white's center knight?
By attacking the pawn defending it.
Also resulting in an attack on the e5 pawn.Is opening up the g file dangerous here? No, because white has no pieces attacking the kingside.
Definitely the c pawn to weaken the king's pawn structure with ideas of Qa5 to shift the attack to the queenside.
We would like to get over to the juicy c3 square to attack (and hopefully fork something) in white's cramped position.
This appears to be a mistake because Qxe1 is possible.
However, black can force the queen back onto a forkable square.
Now black has an abundance of material to work with to win.
Gaining more material with the threat of the passed pawn.
Now we turn our attention to pushing the other passed pawns.
The bishop is doing double duty and is soon to crumble under the pressure.

Black has some development issues due to white's pawn controlling the natural squares for the bishop and the knight, restricting them to developing e7 which will block the other from developing. To fix this, black must move one of them twice.
Moving the knight first with ideas of planting it on d5.
This appears to sac a pawn, however black has Nc3 to win the trapped rook.
Black has a couple of options here. Simple development with bf7 is a move, however there is a material winning trade.
The pawn is now hanging, which piece to take with?
The queen is better as it defends black's e3 pawn.
No need to rush things, just develop the bishop. White does not have any concrete threats and black sets themselves up for castling kingside.
Again, more development in exchange for the pawn.
Ideas of doubling on the open d file.
Trading is now fine with material advantage and we are not going out of the way to do so.
0-1 Black wins. Now really preventing white from playing g4 threatening en-passant
However, for now we develop the knight first.
Temporarily sacrificing the knight for center control and a pawn fork.
White chooses not to take so black is just up a pawn and can still play d5 for center control also defending the knight.
Yes, an even material trade plus ruining white's pawn structure.
The game may have continued here and this is why we take with the knight.
Skewering the queen and the rook.
Different from the other lines, but we can adhere to our development principles here. Could occupy the center or develop the knight.
Developing the knight and tightening control of the center.
Developing and defending the pawn.
This pin is annoying, how can we break the pin without bringing the bishop back to e2?

With ideas of getting rid of the pin. Note that at first this move looks passive, however it is okay when the opponent has chosen a very passive line, white is still ahead in development. White is also not concerned about castling as the king is safe in this position and will have the option of castling queenside later.
Getting rid of the pin with ideas of castling queenside.
Getting the king to safety and developing the rook. White does offer the pawn sac here for development.
Here white chooses to open up the center to take advantage of the lead in development when black's king is still stuck in the center.
There are three things that we could capture here. Turns out all three moves lead to a clear advantage according to the engine, but the played move is mot accurate.
Danya style move, sacrificing the bishop really open up the center.

Critical move! This move appears innocuous, but is further developing the bishop into a position to open up the d file so the rooks can be moved into play.The long term idea is to create two mating threats and overload black to checkmate.
Black plays into white's hands and opens up the d file for white.
Overloading and distracting the queen so white can mate.

1-0 White wins by checkmate. Note that this mate was wholly prepared by 16...Bf4, this allowed white to break through the d file and complete the mating attack started by the initial bishop sacrifice.
Following the same line as a previous game.
Throwing a wrench into black's plans with the threat of an exchange that ruins black's structure.
Black has the option to meet c3 with d4 much like the last game but...
... black chooses the knight this time.
This move doesn't look like it accomplishes much but the idea is...

... to allow black to move back to g6 safely and neutralize the threat of white playing f5. Danya emphasizes a "15 second rule" for calculating. Once you've calculated a line, take 15 more seconds to see if you are missing anything.
White plays Bg4 again, but now it is too late, black has had a chance to castle and get the king to safety before the center is opened up.
Note here that white's problems down the line are directly related to undeveloped pieces. White spent too many tempi moving the bishop around and it is at the cost of their development.

However, opening up the f file is very beneficial for black due to white's undeveloped pieces. This allows black to leverage their development to gain the initiative and attack white's king before white's pieces can be brought into the game.
Developing the bishop with tempo so black can develop the rook.

0-1 Black wins. Notice where the forced mate is going to be delivered, the opened f file! Black wins by overloading the queen which is tasked with too many defensive jobs. This is directly a result of white's bishop and rook being undeveloped.All of black's pieces in the final position are developed and aimed towards the white's king.
Immediate ideas of opening up the center...
Following the usual plan of developing.
Executing black's plan to attack the king.
Stopping white from playing Nf3 and preparing to check and pin the bishop.
Black has most of their pieces developed, how can they continue the attack?
Allowing Nd3 if white attempts to close the position with d4.
It looks like white is also able to close the position here, but the crucial difference is that this allows the knight to be outposted on d3.
White prevents themselves from playing b3 so Qa4 can be played immediately.
Plans to set up a mating battery.
Thematic move for this game, further opening up the position!
Bringing all of black's pieces into the game.

Attacking the knight and preventing black from castling. An example of dynamic development, choosing developmental ideas tailored to what the opponent is playing vs developing to nice looking squares without a strategic reason.
How can white pressure black's position?
White is allowed to move this pawn again because of their developmental lead. Black's pieces are somewhat stuck so white can take advantage of these weaknesses on the queenside.

White does not trade bishops because this helps improve black's position. By playing a retreating move to support the pawn, white prevents the knight's development. Also note how black's knight is blocked by the bishop.
A multi purpose move. Defending the c4 bishop, x-raying black's king, preparing Bc3 and long castling.
This is a subtle move, threatening Nf7 which would be a fork on the rooks. White also has Bxa6 to break open the position should black castle queenside.
... with the goal of removing the defender so white can win the whole rook.
The series of trades here are great for white. White does not have to go out of the way to find them and the simplification benefits white who is up material.
White continues plans of developing and controlling the center.
Black plays some cross between the French and the Caro Kann. Not good because it is passive, giving white the development lead.
Continuing with development. Not playing e5 to allow the position to open up and allow white to take advantage of their better development.
Nice space for the bishop, defending the knight.
Defending with the piece of lesser value.
Preparing Ng5. This is a key move because even if black does not accept the gift, it allows white to continue attacking and weakening black's kingside defenses.
The purpose of h4 is now revealed.
No matter where black's king goes, checkmate is next.
White has severely weakened d4 since now no white pawn can attack it. This is a good spot for the knight to outpost on.
How can black cement their control on d4?
Preparing to fianchetto the bishop to control d5.
How does black continue to enhance their control over d4?
Ideas of removing one of the defenders.
Black has no need to take the outpost yet.
A seemingly passive move to prepare developing Ne7, however, note how passive white's position is, this gives black some time to develop in this way while maintaining control on d4.
Now is the right time to put the knight on d4 now that black's development is completed.
Lending more support to d4. "Look at these stallions ladies and gentlemen."
Activating the queen to pressure white's position. Okay to move the queen away from the king since white is not attacking.
Starting a queenside attack by preparing b5.
Forcing the trade of bishops so the knight can be forever outposted on d4.
Finally playing b5 to continue the queenside attack that was started with a6.
Guarding f5 and preventing black's bishop from occupying it.
Black wants Bd6, how can white try to contest this idea?
White's knights are a little passive so...
... let's develop one with tempo.
Ruining black's structure with an even material exchange.
A nice hook for an attack by white.
White's attack at this point is stalled. What should white do?
No need to sac the knight, calmly retreating the knight with tempo.
Note that black's f pawn is overloaded needing to defend both e6 and g6.
Continuing to control the e file.
Unpinning the queen, allowing Nxe4 and black will be down a pawn in the exchange.
White's plan is to occupy the center.
Oversupporting the pawn and building a strong, supported center.
Black correctly striking in the center.
Closing the center. Black's bishop has more potential influence now, but soon will not as white plans on trading.
Before trading the bishops, white can start building the attack on the kingside.
Black wins a pawn and has control of the queenside.

Defending and developing. An exception to the rule of not playing Be6 because it blocks the development of the dark squared bishop. however, in this case, white's pawn on f6 provides black with a solution to that problem.
White allowing the diagonal to be opened quite nicely.
White's dark squared bishop is stuck.
Black has ideas of trading queens since black is up pawns and can play a winning endgame.
Notice the open a file, how can black win control over it? Black would like a the knight on c2. However...
The pawn is not blundered because...
Pinning the hanging knight and attacking the piece it is defending. Note how important the rook on the a-file is.
Controlling the center and preventing Nc6.
White would like this square for the bishop.

Ideas of freeing up the c4 square by undermining black's control over the square.See this part of the video where Danya goes over the concept of freeing up a square https://youtu.be/FPI9J8_LmJQ?t=760.
Stopping black from playing a5 themselves. Note that black will have a difficult time removing this pawn.
Defending the pawn and preparing Nd2.
Now the knight has access to some beautiful outposts.
Black's only active piece. How can white remove it?
Leaving the queen to control the open c-file.
Black looking to trap the bishop.
Opening a space for the bishop to retreat to.
Opening a nice square for the bishop to aid in an attack and to protect the pawn's advance into a possible promotion.
Not trading bishops just yet. White would like to trade on their own terms with a chance to attack a hanging pawn.
